titleStmt.title: True Chronicle Historie ofthe life and death of King LEAR and his three Daughters. With the vnfortunate life of Edgar, sonne and heire to the Earle of Gloster, and his sullen and assumed humor of TOM of Bedlam: As it was played before the King's Maiestie at Whitehall vpon S.Stephans night in Christmas Hollidayes. By his Maiesties seruants playing vsually at the Gloabe on the Bancke-side.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Nathaniel Butter, and are to be sold at his shop in Pauls Church-yard at the signe of the Pide Bull neere St. Austins Gate.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Lear; King of Britain Gonorill; daughter to Lear Regan; daughter to Lear Cordelia; daughter to Lear Earl of Kent Earl of Gloster Edgar; son of Gloster Edmund; bastard son of Gloster Duke of Cornwell Duke of Albany Oswald; stewerd to Gonorill Curan; a courtier Duke of Burgundie King of France Old man; tenant to Gloster Gentleman Doctor Foole Herald Seruant 1 Seruant 2 Seruant 3 Knight Messenger Captain

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.head: M. William Shak-speare HIS History, of King Lear. KING LEAR

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: I Thought the King had more affected the Duke of Albany than Cornwell.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
It did always seem so&H52; to&H4; us&Hrp;, but now in&H4; the
division of the kingdoms, it appears not which&H61; of
the Dukes he values most, for&H3; equalities are so&H51; weighed, that&H3; curiosity in&H4; neither, can make choice of either's moiety.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Is not this your son my Lord?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: His breeding sir hath been at my charge, I have so&H51; often blushed to&H9; acknowledge him, that&H3; now I am brazed to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: I cannot conceive you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
Sir, this young fellow's mother Could, whereupon she
grew round-wombed, and had indeed Sir a son for&H4; her&H2; cradle, ere she had a husband for&H4; her&H2; bed, do you smell a fault?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so&H51; proper.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
But I have sir a son by&H4; order of Law, some year elder than this, who&H61; yet is no&H2; dearer in&H4; my account, though this
knave came something saucily into the world before he was
sent for&H5;, yet was his mother fair, there was good sport at his
making,andthe whoreson must be acknowledged, do, you know
this noble gentleman Edmund?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: No&H7; my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: My Lord of Kent, remember him hereafter as my honourable friend.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: My services to&H4; your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: I must love you, and sue to&H9; know you better.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Sir I shall study deserving.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
He hath been out nine years, and away he shall
again, the King is coming.

stage.l: Enter one bearing a Coronet, then Lear, then the
Dukes of Albany, and Cornwell, next Gonorill, Regan, Cordelia, with followers.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Attend my Lords of France and Burgundy, Gloster.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I shall my Liege.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Mean time we&Hrp; will&H1; express our&Hrp; darker purposes,
The map there; know we&Hrp; have divided
In&H4; three, our&Hrp; kingdom; and it is our&Hrp; first intent,
To&H9; shake all cares and business of our&Hrp; state,
Confirming them on&H4; younger years,
The two great Princes France and Burgundy,
Great rivals in&H4; our&Hrp; youngest daughters love,
Long in&H4; our&Hrp; Court have made their amorous sojourn,
And here are to&H9; be answered, tell me my daughters,
Which&H62; of you shall we&Hrp; say doth love us&Hrp; most,
That&H3; we&Hrp; our&Hrp; largest bounty may extend,
Where merit doth most challenge it,
Gonorill our&Hrp; eldest borne, speak first?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Sir I do love you more than words can wield the matter,
Dearer than eye-sight, space or liberty,
Beyond what can be valued rich or rare,
No&H2; less than life; with grace, health, beauty, honour,
As much a child ever loved, or father friend,
A love that&H61; makes breath poor, and speech unable,
Beyond all manner of so&H51; much I love you.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: What shall Cordelia do, love and be silent.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Of all these bounds, even from this line to&H4; this,
With shady forests, and wide skirted meads,
We&Hrp; make thee Lady, to&H4; thine and Albaines issue,
Be this perpetual, what says our&Hrp; second daughter?
Our&Hrp; dearest Regan, wife to&H4; Cornwell, speak?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sir I am made of the selfsame metal that&H61; my sister is,
And prize me at her&H2; worth in&H4; my true heart,
I find she names my very deed of love, only she came short,
That&H3; I profess myself an enemy to&H4; all other joys,
Which&H61; the most precious square of sense possesses,
And find I am alone felicitate, in&H4; your dear highness's love.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Then poor Cord.and yet not so&H52;, since I am sure
My love is more richer than my tongue.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: To&H4; thee and thine hereditary ever
Remain this ample third of our&Hrp; fair kingdom,
No&H2; less in&H4; space, validity, and pleasure,
Than that&H62; confirmed on&H4; Gonorill, but now our&Hrp; joy,
Although the last, not least in&H4; our&Hrp; dear love,
What can you say to&H9; win a third, more opulent
your sisters'.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How, nothing can come of nothing, speak again.

sp.speaker: Cord.>
sp.l: Unhappy that&H3; I am, I cannot heave my heart into my
mouth,I love your Majesty according to&H4; my bond, nor more nor less.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Go to&H5;, go to&H5;, mend your speech a little,
Lest it may mar your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cord.>
sp.l: Good my Lord,
You have begot me, bred me, loved me,
I return those duties back as are right fit,
Obey you, love you, and most honour you,
Why have my sisters husbands if they say they love you all,.
Happily when I shall wed, that&H62; Lord whose hand
Must take my plight, shall carry half my love with him,
Half my care and duty, sure I shall never
Marry like&H4; my sisters, to&H9; love my father all.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: But goes this with thy heart?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Aye good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: So&H51; young and so&H51; untender.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: So&H51; young my Lord and true.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Well let it be so&H52;, thy truth then be thy dower,
For&H3; by&H4; the sacred radiance of the Sun,
The mistress of Heccat, and the might,
By&H4; all the operation of the orbs,
From whom we&Htp; do exist and cease to&H9; be
Here I disclaim all my paternal care,
Propinquity and property of blood,
And as a stranger to&H4; my heart and me
Hold thee from this forever, the barbarous Scythyan,
Or he that&H61; makes his generation
Messes to&H9; gorge his appetite
Shall be as well neighboured, pitied and relieved
As thou my sometime daughter.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Liege.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Peace Kent, come not between the Dragon his wrath,
I loved her&H6; most, and thought to&H9; set my rest
On&H4; her&H2; kind nursery, hence and avoid my sight?
So&H52; be my grave my peace as here I give,
Her&H2; father's heart from her&H6;, call France, who&H62; stirs?
Call Burgundy, Cornwell, and Albany,
With my two daughters dower digest this third,
Let pride, which&H61; she calls plainness, marry her&H6;:
I do invest you jointly in&H4; my power,
Pre-eminence, and all the large effects
That&H61; troop with Majesty, ourself by&H4; monthly course
With reservation of an hundred knights,
By&H4; you to&H9; be sustained, shall our&Hrp; abode
Make with you by&H4; due turns, only we&Hrp; still retain
The name and all the additions to&H4; a King,
The sway, revenue, execution of the rest,
Beloved sons be yours,which&H61; to&H9; confirm,
This Coronet part betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Royal Lear,
Whom I have ever honoured as my King,
Loved as my Father, as my master followed,
As my great patron thought on&H5; in&H4; my prayers.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The bow is bent and drawn make from the shaft.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Let it fall rather,
Though the fork invade the region of my heart,
Be Kent unmannerly when Lear is man,
What wilt thou do old man, thinkst thou that&H3; duty
Shall have dread to&H9; speak, when power to&H4; flattery bows,
To&H4; plainness honour is bound when Majesty
stoops to&H4; folly,
Reverse thy doom, and in&H4; thy best consideration
Check this hideous rashness,answer my life
My judgment, thy youngest daughter does not love thee least,
Nor are those empty hearted whose low, sound
Reverbs no&H2; hollowness.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Kent on&H4; thy life no&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My life I never held but as a pawn
To&H9; wage against thy enemies, nor fear to&H9; lose it
Thy safety being the motive.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: See better Lear and let me still remain,
The true blank of thine eye.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Now by&H4; Appollo,

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Now by&H4; Appollo King thou swearest thy Gods in&H4; vain.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Vassal, recreant.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Do, kill thy Physician,
And the fee bestow upon&H4; the foul disease,
Revoke thy doom, or whilst I can vent clamour
From my throat, I will&H1; tell thee thou dost evil.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Hear me, on&H4; thy allegiance hear me?
Since thou hast sought to&H9; make us&Hrp; break our&Hrp; vow,
Which&H61; we&Hrp; durst never yet; and with strayed pride,
To&H9; come between our&Hrp; sentence and our&Hrp; power,
Which&H61; nor our&Hrp; nature nor our&Hrp; place can bear,
Our&Hrp; potency made good,take thy reward,
Four days we&Hrp; do allot thee for&H4; provision,
To&H9; shield thee from diseases of the world,
And on&H4; the fifth to&H9; turn thy hated back
Upon&H4; our&Hrp; kingdom, if on&H4; the tenth day following,
Thy banished trunk be found in&H4; our&Hrp; dominions,
The moment is thy death, away, by&H4; Jupiter
This shall not be revoked.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Why fare thee well king, since thus thou wilt appear,
Friendship lives hence, and banishment is here,
The Gods to&H4; their protection take the maid,
That&H61; rightly thinks, and hast most justly said,
And your large speeches may your deeds approve,
That&H3; good effects may spring from words of love:
Thus Kent O Princes, bids you all adieu,
He will&H1; shape his old course in&H4; a country new.

stage.l: Enter France and Burgundie with Gloster.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here is France and Burgundy my noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: My Lord. of Burgundy,we&Hrp; first address towards you,
Who&H61; with a King hath rivaled for&H4; our&Hrp; daughter,
What in&H4; the least will&H1; you require in&H4; present
Dower with her&H6;, or cease your quest of love?

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Royal majesty,
I crave no&H2; more than what
Your highness offered, nor will&H1; you tender less?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Right noble Burgundy,when she was dear to&H4; us&Hrp;
We&Hrp; did hold her&H6; so&H52;, but now her&H2; prise is fallen,
Sir there she stands, if aught within that&H62; little
Seeming substance, or all of it with our&Hrp; displeasure piecest,
And nothing else may fitly like&H1; your grace,
She is there, and she is yours.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: I know no&H2; answer.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Sir will&H1; you with those infirmities she owes,
unfriended, new adopted to&H4; our&Hrp; hate,
Covered with our&Hrp; curse, and strangered with our&Hrp; oath,
Take her&H6; or leave her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Pardon me royal sir, election makes not up&H5;
On&H4; such conditions.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Then leave her&H6; sir, for&H3; by&H4; the power that&H61; made me
I tell you all her&H2; wealth, for&H4; you great King,
I would not from your love make such a stray,
To&H9; match you where I hate, therefore beseech you,
To&H9; avert your liking a more worthier way,
Than on&H4; a wretch whom nature is ashamed
Almost to&H9; acknowledge hers.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This is most strange, that&H3; she, that&H61; even but now
Was your best object, the argument of your praise,
Balm of your age,most best, most dearest,
Should in&H4; this trice of time commit a thing,
So&H51; monstrous to&H9; dismantle so&H51; many folds of favour,
Sure her&H2; offence must be of such unnatural degree,
That&H61; monsters it, or you for&H4; vouched affections
Fallen into taint, which&H61; to&H9; believe of her&H6;
Must be a faith that&H3; reason without miracle
Could never plant in&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: I yet beseech your Majesty,
If for&H3; I want that&H62; glib and oily Art&H0;,
To&H9; speak and purpose not, since what I well intend
I will&H1;. do it before I speak, that&H3; you may know
It is no&H2; vicious blot, murder or foulness,
No&H2; unclean action or dishonoured step
That&H61; hath deprived me of your grace and favour,
But even for&H4; want of that&H62;, for&H4; which&H61; I am rich,
A still soliciting eye, and such a tongue,
As I am glad I have not, though not to&H9; have it,
Hath lost me in&H4; your liking.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Go to&H5;, go to&H5;, better thou hadst not been borne,
Than not to&H9; have pleased me better.

sp.speaker: Fra.>
sp.l: Is it no&H2; more but this, a tardiness in&H4; nature,
That&H61; often leaves the history unspoke that&H61; it intends to&H9; do,
My Lord of Burgundy,what say you to&H4; the Lady?
Love is not love when it is mingled with respects that&H61; stands
Aloof from the entire point will&H1; you have her&H6;?
She is herself and dower.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Royal Leir,
give but that&H62; portion
Which&H61; yourself proposed,and here I take Cordelia
By&H4; the hand, Duchess of Burgundy,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Nothing, I have sworn.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: I am sorry then you have so&H52; lost a father,
That&H3; you must lose a husband.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Peace be with Burgundy, since that&H3; respects
Of fortune are his love, I shall not be his wife.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fairest Cordelia that&H61; art most rich being poor,
Most choice forsaken,and most loved despised,
Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon&H5;,
Be it lawful I take up&H5; what is. cast away,
Gods, Gods! it is strange,that&H3; from their coldest. neglect,
My love should kindle to&H4; inflamed respect,
Thy dowerless daughter King thrown to&H4; thy chance,
Is Queen of us&Hrp;, of ours&Hrp;,and our&Hrp; fair France:
Not all the Dukes in&H4; waterish Burgundy,
Shall buy this unprized precious maid of me,
Bid them farewell Cordelia, though unkind
Thou losest here, a better where to&H9; find.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thou hast her&H6; France, let her&H6; be thine,
For&H3; we&Hrp; have no&H2; such daughter, nor shall ever see
That&H62; face of hers again,therefore be gone,
Without our&Hrp; grace, our&Hrp; love, our&Hrp; benison? come noble Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Bid farewell to&H4; your sisters?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: The jewels of our&Htp; father,
With washed eyes Cordelia leaves you, I know you what you are,
And like&H4; a sister am most loath to&H9; call your faults
As they are named, use well our&Htp; Father,
To&H4; your professed bosoms I commit him,
But yet alas stood I within his grace,
I would prefer him to&H4; a better place:
So&H3; farewell to&H4; you both?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Prescribe not us&Htp; our&Htp; duties?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Let your study be to&H9; content your Lord,
Who&H61; hath received you at Fortunes alms,
You have obedience scanted,
And well are worth the worth that&H61; you have wanted.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Time shall unfold what pleated cunning hides,
Who&H61; covers faults, at last shame them derides:
Well may you prosper.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come fair Cordelia?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Sister, it is not a little I have to&H9; say,
Of what most nearly appertains to&H4; us&Htp; both,
I think our&Htp; father will&H1; hence tonight.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: That&H62; is most certain, and with you, next month with us&Hrp;.

sp.speaker: Gon.
Reg.
sp.p: It is. the infirmity of his age, yet he hath ever but slenderly known himself.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
The best and soundest of his time hath been but rash,
then must we&Htp; look to&H9; receive from his age not alone the imperfection of long ingrafted condition, but therewithal unruly waywardness, that&H61; infirm and choleric years bring with them.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p:
Such unconstant starts are we&Htp; like&H5; to&H9; have from him, as
this of Kents banishment.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
There is further compliment of leave taking between
France and him,pray let us&Htp; hit together, if our&Htp; Father carry authority with such dispositions as he bears, this last surrender of his,
will&H1; but offend us&Htp;,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: We&Htp; shall further think on&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: We&Htp; must do something, and in&H4; the heat.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Thou Nature art my Goddess, to&H4; thy law my services
are bound, wherefore should I stand in&H4; the plague of custom,
and permit the curiosity of nations to&H9; deprive me, for&H3; that&H3; I am
some twelve or fourteen moonshines lag of a brother, why bastard?
wherefore base, when my dimensions are as well compact, my
mind as generous, and my shape as true as honest madam's issue,
why brand they us&Htp; with base, base bastardy? who&H61; in&H4; the lusty
stealth of nature, take more composition and fierce quality,than
doth within a stale dull lied bed, go to&H4; the creating of a whole
tribe of fops got tween asleep and wake; well the legitimate
Edgar I must have your land, our&Htp; Father's love is to&H4; the bastard
Edmund as to&H4; the legitimate, well my legitimate, if this letter
speed,and my invention thrive, Edmund the base
shall to&H4; the legitimate: I grow, I prosper, now Gods stand up&H5; for&H4; Bastards.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Kent banished thus, and France in&H4; choler parted, and
the King gone tonight, subscribed his power, confined to&H4; exhibition, all this done upon&H4; the gad; Edmund how now
what news?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: So&H3; please your Lordship, none:

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Why so&H51; earnestly seek you to&H9; put up&H5; that&H62; letter?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I know no&H2; news my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: What paper were you reading?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Nothing my Lord,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
No&H7;, what needs then that&H62; terrible dispatch of it into
your pocket, the quality of nothing hath not such need to&H9; hide
itself, let us&Htp; see, come if it be nothing I shall not need spectacles.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I beseech you Sir pardon me, it is a letter from my brother,
that&H61; I have not all over-read, for&H3; so&H51; much as I have perused, I find it
not fit for&H4; your liking.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Give me the letter sir.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I shall offend either to&H9; detain or give it, the contents
as in&H4; part I understand them, are to&H4; blame.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Let us&Htp; see, let us&Htp; see?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I hope for&H4; my brothers justification, he wrote this but
as an essay, or taste of my vertue.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
This policy of age makes the world bitter to&H4; the best
of our&Htp; times, keeps our&Htp; fortunes from us&Htp; till our&Htp; oldness cannot
relish them, I begin to&H9; find an idle and fond bondage in&H4; the oppression of aged tyranny, who&H61; sways not as it hath power, but as
it is suffered, come to&H4; me, that&H3; of this I may speak more, if our&Htp;
father would sleep till I waked him, you should enjoy half his
revenue forever, and live the beloved of your brother Edgar.
Hum, conspiracy, slept till I waked him, you should enjoy half
his revenue, my son Edgar, had he a hand to&H9; write this, a
hart,and brain to&H9; breed it in&H5;, when came this to&H4; you, who&H61;
brought it?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
It was not brought me my Lord, there is the cunning of
it, I found it thrown in&H5; at the casement of my closet.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: You know the Character to&H9; be your brother's?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If the matter were good, my Lord I durst swear it were
his but in&H4; respect, of that&H62; I would fain think it were not,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: It is his?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
It is his hand my Lord, but I hope his heart is not in&H4;
the contents.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Hath he never heretofore sounded you in&H4; this business?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
Never my Lord, but I have often heard him maintain
it to&H9; be fit, that&H3; sons at perfect age,and fathers declining, his father
should be as ward to&H4; the son, and the son manage the revenue.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
O villain, villain, his very opinion in&H4; the letter, abhorred villain, unnatural detested brutish villain, worse than
brutish, go sir seek him, I apprehend him, abominable villain
where is he?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I do not well know my Lord, if it shall please you to&H9;
suspend your indignation against my brother, till you can derive
from him better testimony of this intent: you should run a certain course, where if you violently proceed against him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great gap in&H4; your own
honour,andshake in&H4; pieces the heart of his obedience, I dare pawn
down my life for&H4; him, he hath wrote this to&H9; feel my affection
to&H4; your honour, and to&H4; no&H2; further pretence of danger.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Think you so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If your honour judge it meet, I will&H1; place you where
you shall hear us&Htp; confer of this, and by&H4; an auricular assurance
have your satisfaction, and that&H62; without any further delay than
this very evening.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: He cannot be such a monster.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Nor is not sure.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
To&H4; his father, that&H61; so&H51; tenderly and entirely loves him,
heaven and earth! Edmund seek him out, wind me into him, I
pray you frame your business after your own wisdom, I would
unstate myself to&H9; be in&H4; a due resolution.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I shall seek him sir presently, convey the business as I
shall see means, and acquaint you withal.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
These late eclipses in&H4; the Sun and Moon portend
no&H2; good to&H4; us&Htp;, though the wisdom of nature can reason thus
and thus, yet nature finds itself scourged by&H4; the sequent effects,
love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide, in&H4; Cities mutinies, in&H4; Countries discords, Palaces treason, the bond cracked
between son and father; find out this villain Edmund, it shall
lose thee nothing, do it carefully, and the noble and true hearted Kent banished, his offence honest, strange strange!

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
This is the excellent foppery of the world, that&H3; when
we&Htp; are sick in&H4; Fortune, often the surfeit of our&Htp; own behaviour,
we&Htp; make guilty of our&Htp; disasters, the Sun, the Moon, and the
Stars, as if we&Htp; were Villains by&H4; necessity, Fools by&H4; heavenly compulsion, Knaues, Thieves, and Treacherers by&H4; spiritual
predominance, Drunkards, Liars,and Adulterers by&H4; an enforced
obedience of planetary influence, and all that&H61; we&Htp; are evil in&H5;,
by&H4; a divine thrusting on&H5;, an admirable evasion of whoremaster
man, to&H9; lay his goatish disposition to&H4; the charge of Stars: my
Father compounded with my Mother under the Dragon's tail,
and my nativity was under Vrsa major, so&H3; that&H3; it follows,I am
rough and lecherous, Fut,I should have been that&H62; I am, had the
maidenliest star of the Firmament twinkled on&H4; my bastardy
er EdgarEdgar; and out he comes like&H4; the Catastrophe of the old Comedy, mine is villainous melancholy, with a sigh like&H4; them of
Bedlam; O these eclipses do portend these divisions.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: How now brother Edmund, what serious contemplation are you in&H5;?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I am thinking brother of a prediction I read this other
day, what should follow these Eclipses.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Do you busy yourself about that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I promise you the effects he writ of, succeed unhappily,
as of unnaturalness between the child and the parent, death,
dearth, dissolutions of ancient amities, divisions in&H4; state, menaces and maledictions against King and nobles, needles diffidences, banishment of friends, dissipation of Cohorts, nuptial breaches, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: How long have you been a sectary Astronomical?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Come, come, when saw you my father last?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Why, the night gon by&H5;.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Spake you with him?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Two hours together.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
Parted you in&H4; good terms? found you no&H2; displeasure
in&H4; him by&H4; word or countenance?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: None at all.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
Bethink yourself wherein you may have offended
him, and at my entreaty, forbear his presence, till some little
time hath qualified the heat of his displeasure, which&H61; at this instant so&H51; rageth in&H4; him, that&H3; with the mischief,of your person it
would scarce allay.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Some villain hath done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
That&H62; is my fear brother, I advise you to&H4; the best, go
armed, I am no&H2; honest man if there be any good meaning towards you, I have told you what I have seen andheard, but faintly, nothing like&H4; the image and horror of it, pray you away

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Shall I hear from you anon?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I do serve you in&H4; this business:

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: A credulous Father, and a brother noble,
Whose nature is so&H51; far from doing harms,
That&H3; he suspects none, on&H4; whose foolish honesty
My practises ride easy, I see the business,
Let me if not by&H4; birth, have lands by&H4; wit,
All with me is meet, that&H61; I can fashion fit.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Did my Father strike my gentleman for&H4; chiding of his
fool?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: By&H4; day and night he wrongs me,
Every hour he flashes into one gross crime or other
That&H61; sets us&Htp; all at odds, I will&H1; not endure it,
His Knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us&Htp;,
On&H4; every trifle when he returns from hunting,
I will&H1; not speak with him, say I am sick,
If you come slack of former services,
You shall do well, the fault of it I will&H1; answer.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: He is coming Madam, I hear him.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Put on&H5; what weary negligence you please, you and your
fellow servants, I would have it come in&H4; question, if he dislike it, let
him to&H4; our&Hrp; sister, whose mind and mine I know in&H4; that&H62; are one,
not to&H9; be overruled; idle old man that&H61; still would manage those
authorities that&H61; he hath given away, now by&H4; my life old fools
are babes again, and must be used with checks as flatteries, when
they are seen abused, remember what I tell you.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Very well Madam.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: And let his Knights have colder looks among you, what
grows of it no&H2; matter, advise your fellows so&H52;, I would breed
from hence occasions, and I shall, that&H3; I may speak, I will&H1; write
straight to&H4; my sister to&H9; hold my very course, go prepare for&H4;
dinner.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: If but as well I other accents borrow, that&H61; can my speech
defuse, my good intent may carry through itself to&H4; that&H62; full issue for&H4; which&H61; I razed my likeness, now banished Kent, if thou canst
serve where thou dost stand condemned, thy master whom thou
lovest shall find thee full of labour.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Let me not stay a jot for&H4; dinner, go get it ready, how
now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: A man Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What dost thou profess? what wouldst thou with us&Hrp;?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
I do profess to&H9; be no&H2; less than I seem, to&H9; serve him
truly that&H61; will&H1; put me in&H4; trust, to&H9; love him that&H61; is honest, to&H9; converse with him that&H61; is wise, and says little, to&H9; fear judgment,
to&H9; fight when I cannot choose, and to&H9; eat no&H2; fish.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the king.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
If thou be as poor for&H4; a subject, as he is for&H4; a King, thou art
poor enough, what wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Service.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Who&H62; wouldst thou serve?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Dost thou know me fellow?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
No&H7; sir, but you have that&H62; in&H4; your countenance, which&H61;
I would fain call Master.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What is that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Authority.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What services canst do?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious
tale in&H4; telling it, and deliver a plain message bluntly, that&H62;
which&H61; ordinary men are fit for&H5;, I am qualified in&H5;, and the best
of me, is diligence.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: How old art thou?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Not so&H51; young to&H9; love a woman for&H4; singing, nor so&H51; old to&H9;
dote on&H4; her&H6; for&H4; anything, I have years on&H4; my back forty eight.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Follow me, thou shalt serve me, if I like&H1; thee no&H2;
worse after dinner, I will&H1; not part from thee yet, dinner, ho dinner, where is my knave, my fool, go you and call my fool hither, you sirrah,where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: So&H3; please you,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
What says the fellow there, call the clot-pole back,
where is my fool, ho I think the world is asleep, how now,
where is that&H62; mongrel?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: He says my Lord, your daughter is not well.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Why came not the slave back to&H4; me when I called
him?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Sir, he answered me in&H4; the roundest manner, he
would not.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: He would not?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
My Lord, I know not what the matter is, but to&H4; my
judgment, your highness is not entertained with that&H62; ceremonious
affection as you were wont, there is a great abatement, appears as
well in&H4; the general dependants, as in&H4; the Duke himself also,
and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Ha, sayst thou so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
I beseech you pardon me my Lord, if I be mistaken,
for&H3; my duty cannot be silent, when I think your highness
wronged.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception, I
have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which&H61; I have rather
blamed as mine own jealous curiosity, than as a very pretence and
purport of unkindness, I will&H1; look further into it, but where is
this fool? I have not seen him this two days.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Since my young Lady's going into France sir, the fool
hath much pined away.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
No&H2; more of that&H62;, I have noted it, go you and tell my
daughter, I would speak with her&H6;, go you call hither my fool,
O you sir, you sir, come you hither, who&H62; am I sir?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: My Lady's Father.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
My Lady's father, my Lord's knave, you whoreson dog,
you slave, you cur.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p:
I am none of this my Lord,
I beseech you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Do you bandy looks with me you rascal?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: I will&H1;. not be struck my Lord,

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Nor tripped neither, you base football player

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: I thank thee fellow, thou servest me, and I will&H1; love thee

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Come sir I will&H1; teach you differences, away, away, if
you will&H1; measure your lubber's length again, tarry, but away,
you have wisdom.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Now friendly knave I thank thee, there is earnest of
thy service.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Let me hire him too, here is my coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: How now my pretty knave, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Sirrah, you were best take my coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Why Fool?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Why for&H4; taking one's part, that&H61; is out of favour, nay and
thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou wilt catch cold shortly,
there take my coxcomb; why this fellow hath banished two
of his daughters, and done the third a blessing against his will&H0;, if
thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb, how
now nuncle, would I had two coxcombs, and two daughters.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Why my boy?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
If I gave them any living, I would keep my coxcombs
myself, there is mine, beg another of thy daughters.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Take heed sirrah, the whip.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Truth is a dog that&H61; must to&H4; kennel, he must be whipped
out, when Lady the brach may stand by&H4; the fire and stink.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: A pestilent gull to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Sirrah I will&H1; teach thee a speech.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Mark it uncle, have more than thou showest, speak
less than thou knowest, lend less than thou owest, ride more
than thou goest, learn more than thou trowest, set less than
thou throwest, leave thy drink and thy whore, and keep in&H4; a
door, and thou shalt have more, than two tens to&H4; a score.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: This is nothing fool.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Then like&H4; the breath of an unfeed Lawyer, you gave
me nothing for&H4; it, can you make no&H2; use of nothing uncle?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Why no&H7; boy, nothing can be made out of nothing.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Prithee tell him so&H51; much the rent of his land comes to&H5;,
he will&H1; not believe a fool.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: A bitter fool.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Dost know the difference my boy, between a bitter
fool, and a sweet fool.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: No&H7; lad, teach me.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
That&H62; Lord that&H61; counselled thee to&H9; give away thy land,
Come place him here by&H4; me, do thou for&H4; him stand,
The sweet and bitter fool will&H1; presently appear,
The one in&H4; motley here, the other found out there.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Dost thou call me fool boy?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
All thy other Titles thou hast given away, that&H62; thou
wast borne with.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: This is not altogether fool my Lord.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
No&H7; faith, Lords and great men will&H1; not let me, if I had
a monopoly out, they would have part of it, and Ladies too,they
will&H1; not let me have all the fool to&H4; myself, they will&H1; be snatching;
give me an egg Nuncle, and I will&H1; give thee two crowns.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What two crowns shall they be?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Why, after I have cut the egg in&H4; the middle and eat up&H5; the meat, the two crowns of the egg; when thou clovest
thy crown in&H4; the middle, and gavest away both parts, thou borest
thy ass on&H4; the back over the dirt, thou hadst little wit in&H4; thy bald
crown, when thou gavest thy golden one away, if I speak like&H4;
myself in&H4; this, let him be whipped that&H61; first finds it so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Fools had never less wit, in&H4; a year,
For&H3; wise men are grown foppish,
They know not how their wits do wear,
Their manners are so&H51; apish.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: When were you wont to&H9; be so&H51; full of songs sirrah?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
I have used it nuncle, ever since thou madest thy daughters thy mother, for&H3; when thou gavest them the rod, and puttest
down thine own breeches, then they for&H4; sudden joy did weep,
and I for&H4; sorrow sung, that&H3; such a King should play bo-peep,
and go the fools among: prithee Nuncle keep a schoolmaster that&H61; can teach thy fool to&H9; lie, I would fain learn to&H9; lie.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: If you lie, we&Htp; will&H1; have you whipped.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are, they will&H1;
have me whipped for&H4; speaking true, thou wilt have me whipped for&H4; lying, and sometime I am whipped for&H4; holding my peace, I had
rather be any kind of thing than a fool,and yet I would not be
thee Nuncle, thou hast pared thy wit on&H4; both sides, andleft nothing
in&H4; the middle, here comes one of the parings.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How now daughter, what makes that&H62; Frontlet on&H5;,
Methinks you are too much a-late in&H4; the frown.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no&H2; need
to&H9; care for&H4; her&H2; frown, now thou art an O without a figure, I am
better than thou art now, I am a fool,thou art nothing, yes forsooth I will&H1; hold my tongue, so&H52; your face bids me, though
you say nothing.
Mum, mum, he that&H61; keeps neither crust nor crumb,
Weary of all, shall want some. That&H62; is a shelled peascod.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Not only sir this, your all-licenced fool, but other of
your insolent retinue do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking
forth in&H4; rank and (not to&H9; be endured riots,) Sir I had thought by&H4;
making this well known unto you, to&H9; have found a safe redress,
but now grow fearful by&H4; what yourself too late have spoke
and done, that&H3; you protect this course, and put on&H5; by&H4; your allowance, which&H61; if you should, the fault would not scape censure,
nor the redress, sleep, which&H61; in&H4; the tender of a wholesome
weal, might in&H4; their working do you that&H62; offence, that&H61; else
were shame, that&H61; then necessity must call discreet proceedings.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
For&H4; you trow nuncle, the hedge sparrow fed the Cuckoo so&H51; long, that&H3; it had it head bit off by&H4; its young, so&H52; out went
the candle, and we&Htp; were left darkling.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Are you our&Hrp; daughter?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: sir, I would you would make use of that&H62; good
wisdom whereof I know you are fraught, and put away these
dispositions, that&H61; of late transform you from what you rightly
are.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
May not an Ass know when the cart draws the horse,
whoop Jug I love thee.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Doth any here know me? why this is not Lear, doth
Lear walk thus? speak thus? where are his eyes, either his notion, weakness, or his discernings are lethargy, sleeping,or waking; ha! sure it is not so&H52;, who&H62; is it that&H61; can tell me who&H61; I am? Lears
shadow? I would learn that&H62;, for&H3; by&H4; the marks of sovereignty,
knowledge, and reason, I should be false persuaded I had
daughters.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Which&H61; they, will&H1; make an obedient father.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Your name fair gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Come sir, this admiration is much of the savour of other
your new pranks, I do beseech you understand my purposes
aright, as you are old and reverend, should be wise, here do you
keep a hundred Knights and Squires, men so&H51; disordered, so&H51; debauched
and bold, that&H3; this our&Hrp; court infected with their manners, shows
like&H4; a riotous Inn, epicurism, and lust make more like&H4; a tavern
or brothel, than a great palace, the shame itself doth speak
for&H4; instant remedy, be thou desired by&H4; her&H6;, that&H61; else will&H1; take the
thing she begs, a little to&H9; disunited your train, and the remainder that&H61; shall still depend, to&H9; be such men as may besort
your age, that&H61; know themselves and you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Darkness,and Devils! saddle my horses, call my train
together, degenerate bastard, I will&H1; not trouble thee, yet have I left
a daughter.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: You strike my people, and your disordered rabble, make
servants of their betters.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: We&Hrp; that&H61; too late repent us&Htp;, O sir, are you come? is it your
will&H0; that&H3; we&Hrp; prepare any horses,ingratitude! thou marble-hearted fiend, more hideous when thou showest thee in&H4; a child, than
the Sea-monster, detested kite, thou list my train, and men of
choice and rarest parts, that&H61; all particulars of duty know, and
in&H4; the most exact regard, support the worships of their name, O
most small fault, how ugly didst thou in&H4; Cordelia show, that&H61;
like&H4; an engine wrenched my frame of nature from the fixed place,
drew from my heart all love and added to&H4; the gall, O Lear. Lear!
beat at this gate that&H61; let thy folly in&H5;, and thy dear judgment
out, go go, my people?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My Lord, I am guiltless as I am ignorant.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: It may be so&H52; my Lord, hark Nature,hear dear Goddess, suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend to&H9; make this
creature fruitful into her&H2; womb, convey sterility, dry up&H5; in&H4; her&H6;
the organs of increase, and from her&H2; derogate body never spring
a babe to&H9; honour her&H6;, if she must teem, create her&H2; child of
spleen, that&H3; it may live and be a thwart disnatured torment to&H4;
her&H6;, let it stamp wrinkles in&H4; her&H2; brow of youth, with accent
tears, fret channels in&H4; her&H2; cheeks,turn all her&H2; mother's pains
and benefits to&H4; laughter and contempt, that&H3; she may feel,that&H3;
she may feel, how sharper than a serpent's tooth it is, to&H9; have a
thankless child, go, go,my people?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Now Gods that&H61; we&Htp; adore, whereof comes this!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Never afflict yourself to&H9; know the cause, but let his
disposition have that&H62; scope that&H61; dotage gives it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What, fifty of my followers at a clap, within a fortnight?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What is the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1;. tell thee, life and death! I am ashamed
that&H3; thou hast
power to&H9; shake my manhood thus, that&H3; these hot tears that&H61;
break from me perforce.should make the worst blasts and fogs
upon&H4; the untented woundings of a father's curse, pierce every
sense about the old fond eyes, beweep this cause again, I will&H1;
pluck you out, and you cast with the waters that&H61; you make to&H9; temper clay, yea, is it come to&H4; this? yet have I left a daughter, whom
I am sure is kind and comfortable, when she shall hear this of
thee, with her&H2; nails she will&H1; flay thy wolfish visage, thou shalt
find that&H3; I will&H1; resume the shape, which&H61; thou dost think I have cast
off forever, thou shalt I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Do you mark that&H62; my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I cannot be so&H51; partial Gonorill
to&H4; the great love I
bear you,

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Come sir no&H2; more,
you, more knave than fool, after
your master?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Nuncle Lear, Nuncle Lear, tarry and take the fool with a fox when one has caught her&H6;, and such a daughter should sure to&H4; the slaughter, if my cap would buy a halter, so&H52; the fool follows after.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What Oswald, ho.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Here Madam,

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What have you writ this letter to&H4; my sister?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Take you some company, and away to&H4; horse,
her&H6; full of my particular fears, and thereto add such reasons of
your own, as may compact it more, get you gon, and hasten your
return now my Lord, this mild gentleness and course of yours
though I dislike not, yet under pardon you are much more at task
for&H4; want of wisdom, than praise for&H4; harmful mildness

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How far your eyes may pearce I cannot tell, striving to&H9; better aught, we&Htp; mar what is. well.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Well, well, the event,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Go you before to&H4;
Gloster with these letters, acquaint
my daughter no&H2; further with anything you know, than comes
from her&H2; demand out of the letter, if your diligence be not speedy, I shall be there before you.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
I will&H1; not sleep my Lord, till I have delivered your
letter.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: If a man's brains where in&H4; his heels, were it not in&H4; danger of kibes?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Aye boy.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Then I prithee be merry, thy wit shall never go slipshod.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Foole.
Lear.
sp.p: Why what canst thou tell my boy?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
She will&H1; taste as like&H4; this, as a crab doth to&H4; a crab, thou
canst not tell why one's nose stand in&H4; the middle of his face?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Why, to&H9; keep his eyes on&H4; either side his nose, that&H3; what
a man cannot smell out, a may spy into.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I did her&H6; wrong.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Canst tell how an Oyster makes his shell.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Nor I neither, but I can tell why a snail has a house.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Why, to&H9; put his head in&H5;, not to&H9; give it away to&H4; his
daughter, and leave his horns without a case.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1; forget my nature, so&H51; kind a father; be my horses
ready?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Thy Asses are gone about them, the reason why the
seven stars are no&H2; more than seven, is a pretty reason.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Because they are not eight.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Yes thou wouldst make a good fool.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: To&H9; take it again perforce, Monster,ingratitude!

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
If thou wert my fool Nuncle,I would have thee beaten for&H4;
being old before thy time.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How is that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Thou shouldst not have been old, before thou hadst
been wise.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O let me not be mad sweet heaven! I would not be mad,
keep me in&H4; temper, I would not be mad, are the horses ready?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Ready my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come boy.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: She that&H61; is maid now,and laughs at my departure,
Shall not be a maid long, except things be cut shorter.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Save thee Curan.

sp.speaker: Curan.
sp.p:
And you Sir, I have been with your father, and given
him notice, that&H3; the Duke of Cornwall and his Duchess will&H1; be
here with him tonight.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: How comes that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Curan.
sp.p:
Nay, I know not,you have heard of the news abroad,
I mean the whispered ones, for&H3; there are yet but ear-bussing arguments.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Not, I pray you what are they?

sp.speaker: Curan.
sp.p:
Have you heard of no&H2; likely wars towards, twixt
the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Curan.
sp.p: You may then in&H4; time, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: The Duke be here tonight! the better best, this weaves

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: itself perforce into my business, my father hath set guard to&H9; take
my brother, and I have one thing of a queasy question, which&H61;
must ask briefness and fortune help; brother, a word, descend
brother I say, my father watches, O fly this place, intelligence
is given where you are hid, you have now the good advantage
of the night, have you not spoken gainst the Duke of Cornwall
aught, he is coming hither now in&H4; the night, in&H4; the haste, and Regan with him, have you nothing said upon&H4; his party against the
Duke of Albany,advise your---

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I am sure on&H4; it not a word.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I hear my father coming, pardon me in&H4; craving, I must
draw my sword upon&H4; you,seem to&H9; defend yourself, now quit
you well, yield, come before my father, light here, here, fly
brother fly, torches, torches, so&H3; farewell; some blood drawn
on&H4; me would beget opinion of my more fierce endeavour, I
have seen drunkards do more than this in&H4; sport, father, father,
stop, stop, no&H7;, help?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now Edmund where is the villain?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Here stood he in&H4; the dark, his sharpe sword out, warbling of wicked charms, conjuring the Moon to&H9; stand his auspicious Mistress.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But where is he?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Look sir, I bleed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Where is the villain Edmund?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Fled this way sir, when by&H4; no&H2; means he could---

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Pursue him, go after, by&H4; no&H2; means, what?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Persuade me to&H4; the murder of your Lordship, but that&H3;
I told him the revenge Gods, gainst Parricides did all their
thunders bend, spoke with how manifold and strong a bond
the child was bound to&H4; the father, sir in&H4; a fine, seeing how loathly opposite I stood, to&H4; his unnatural purpose, with fell motion
with his prepared sword, he charges home my unprovided body, launched mine arm, but when he saw my best alarmed spirits,
bold in&H4; the quarrels, rights, roused to&H4; the encounter, or whether
ghasted by&H4; the noise I made, but suddenly he fled.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let him fly far, not in&H4; this land shall he remain uncaught and found, dispatch, the noble Duke my master, my
worthy Arch and Patron, comes tonight, by&H4; his authority I will&H1;
proclaim it, that&H3; he which&H61; finds him shall deserve our&Hrp; thanks,
bringing the murderous caitiff to&H4; the stake, he that&H61; conceals
him, death.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: When I dissuaded him from his intent, and found him
pight to&H9; do it, with cursed speech I threatened to&H9; discover him, he
replied, thou unpossessing Bastard, dost thou think, if I would
stand against thee, could the reposure of any trust, vertue, or
worth in&H4; thee make thy words faithed? no&H7;. what I should deny,
as this I would, I, though thou didst produce my very character,
I would turn it all to&H4; thy suggestion, plot, and damned pretence,
and thou must make a dullard of the world, if they not thought
the profits of my death, were very pregnant and potential
spurs to&H9; make thee seek it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Strong and fastened villain, would he deny his letter,
I never got him, hark the Duke's trumpets, I know not why he
comes, all Ports I will&H1; bar, the villain shall not scape, the Duke
must grant me that&H62;, besides, his picture I will&H1; send far and
near, that&H3; all the kingdom may have note of him, and of my
land loyal and natural boy, I will&H1; work the means to&H9; make thee
capable.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: How now my noble friend, since I came hither, which&H61;
I can call but now, I have heard strange news.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: If it be true, all vengeance comes too short which&H61; can
pursue the offender, how dost my Lord?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Madam my old heart is cracked, is cracked.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: What, did my father's godson seek your life? he whom
my father named your Edgar?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye Lady, Lady, shame would have it hid.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Was he not companion with the riotous knights, that&H61;
tends upon&H4; my father?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know not Madam, it is too bad, too bad.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Yes Madam,he was.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: No&H2; marvel then though he were ill affected,
It is. they have put him on&H4; the old man's death,
To&H9; have the waste and spoil of his revenues:
I have this present evening from my sister,
Been well informed of them,and with such cautions,
That&H3; if they come to&H9; sojourn at my house, I will&H1; not be there.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Nor I, assure thee Regan; Edmund, I heard that&H3; you
have shown your father a child-like office.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: It was my duty Sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He did betray his practise, and received
This hurt you see, striving to&H9; apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Is he pursued?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: If he be taken, he shall never more be feared of doing
harm, make your own purpose how in&H4; my strength you please,
for&H4; you Edmund, whose vertue and obedience, doth this instant
so&H51; much commend itself, you shall be ours&Hrp;, natures of such
deep trust, we&Hrp; shall much need you, we&Hrp; first seize on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I shall serve you truly, however else.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: For&H4; him I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: You know not why we&Htp; came to&H9; visit you?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Thus out of season, threatening dark-eyed night,
Occasions noble Gloster of some prise,
Wherein we&Htp; must have use of your advise,
Our&Htp; Father he hath writ, so&H52; hath our&Htp; sister,
Of differences, which&H61; I lest thought it fit,
To&H9; answer from our&Htp; home,the several messengers
From hence attend dispatch,our&Hrp; good old friend,
Lay comforts to&H4; your bosom,and bestow your needful counsel
To&H4; our&Htp; business, which&H61; craves the instant use.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I serve you Madam, your Graces are right welcome.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Good even to&H4; thee friend, art of the house?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Where may we&Htp; set our&Htp; horses?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: In&H4; the mire.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Prithee if thou love me, tell me.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: I love thee not.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Why then I care not for&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
If I had thee in&H4; Lipsburie pinfold, I would make thee
care for&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Why dost thou use me thus? I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Fellow I know thee.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: What dost thou know me for&H5;?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
A knave, a rascal, an eater of broken meats, a base,
proud, shallow, beggarly, three suited hundred pound, filthy
worsted-stocking knave, a lily-livered action taking knave, a
whoreson glass-gazing superfinicall rogue, one trunk inheriting slave, one that&H61; wouldst be a bawd in&H4; way of good service,
and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pander, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch, whom
I will&H1; beat into clamorous whining, if thou deny the least syllable of the addition.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p:
What a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to&H9; rail on&H4; one,
that&H61; is neither known of thee, nor knows thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
What a brazen faced varlet art thou, to&H9; deny thou
knowest me, is it two days ago since I beat thee,and tripped up&H5;
thy heels before the King? draw you rogue, for&H3; though it be
night the Moon shines, I will&H1; make a sop of the moonshine of you,
draw you whoreson cullionly barber-monger, draw?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Away, I have nothing to&H9; do with thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Draw you rascal, you bring letters against the King,
and take Vanity the puppet's part, against the royalty of her&H2;
father, draw you rogue or I will&H1; so&H51; carbonado your shanks, draw
you rascal, come your ways.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Help, ho, murther,help.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Strike you slave, stand rogue, stand you neat slave,
strike?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: Help, ho, murther, help.

div2.stage: Enter Edmund with his rapier drawne, Gloster the Duke and Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: How now, what is. the matter?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
With you goodman boy, if you please come, I will&H1;
flesh you, come on&H5; young master.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Weapons, arms, what is. the matter here?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Keep peace upon&H4; your lives, he dies that&H61; strikes again, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.p: The messengers from our&Hrp; sister, and the King.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: What is your difference, speak?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p: I am scarce in&H4; breath my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
No&H2; marvel you have so&H51; bestirred your valour, you
cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in&H4; thee, a Tailor made thee.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Thou art a strange fellow, a Tailor make a man.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Aye, a Tailor sir; a Stone-cutter, or a Painter could not
have made him so&H51; ill, though he had been but two hours at
the trade.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Speak yet, how grew your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p:
This ancient ruffian sir, whose life I have spared at suit
of his gray-beard.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Thou whoreson Zed, thou unnecessary letter, my
Lord if you will&H1; give me leave, I will&H1; tread this unbolted villain
into mortar, and daub the walls of a jakes with him, spare
my gray beard you wagtail.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Peace sir, you beastly Knave you have no&H2; reverence.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Yes sir, but anger has a privilege.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Why art thou angry?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: That&H3; such a slave as this should wear a sword,
That&H61; wears no&H2; honesty, such smiling rogues as these,
Like&H4; Rats oft bite those cords in&H4; twain,
Which&H61; are to&H9; entrench, to&H9; unloose smooth every passion
That&H61; in&H4; the natures of their Lords rebel,
Bring oil to&H9; stir, snow to&H4; their colder-moods,
Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks
With every gale and vary of their masters,
Knowing naught like&H4; days but following, a plague upon&H4; your epileptic
Visage, smile you my speeches, as I were a fool?
Goose if I had you upon&H4; Sarum plain,
I would send you cackling home to&H4; Camulet.,

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: What art thou mad old fellow?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: How fell you out,say that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No&H2; contraries hold more, antipathy,
Than I and such a knave.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Why dost thou call him knave, what is his offence.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: His countenance likes me not.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: No&H2; more perchance does mine, or his, or hers.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Sir it is my occupation to&H9; be plain,
I have seen better faces in&H4; my time
That&H61; stands on&H4; any shoulder that&H61; I see
Before me at this instant.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: This is a fellow who&H61; having been praised
For&H4; bluntness doth affect a saucy roughness,
And constrains the garb quite from his nature,
He cannot flatter he, he must be plain,
He must speak truth,and they will&H1; take it so&H52;,
If not he is plain, these kind of knaues I know
Which&H61; in&H4; this plainness harbour more craft,
And more corrupter ends, than twenty silly ducking
Observants, that&H61; stretch their duties nicely.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Sir in&H4; good sooth, or in&H4; sincere verity,
Under the allowance of your grand aspect.
Whose influence like&H4; the wreath of radiant fire
In&H4; flickering Phoebus front.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: What meanest thou by&H4; this?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
To&H9; go out of my dialogue which&H61; you discommend so&H51;
much, I know sir, I am no&H2; flatterer, he that&H61; beguiled you in&H4; a plain
accent, was a plain knave, which&H61; for&H4; my part I will&H1; not be,
though I should win your displeasure, to&H9; entreat me to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: What is the offence you gave him?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I never gave him any, it pleased the King his master
Very late to&H9; strike at me upon&H4; his misconstruction,
When he conjunctive and flattering his displeasure
Tripped me behind, being down, insulted, railed,
And put upon&H4; him such a deal of man, that&H3;,
That&H62; worthied him, got praises of the King,
For&H4; him attempting who&H61; was self subdued,
And in&H4; the fleshment of this dread exploit,
Drew on&H4; me here again.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: None of these rogues and cowards but AIax is their fool.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bring forth the stocks ho?
You stubborn miscreant knave, you reverent braggart,
We&Htp; will&H1; teach you.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I am too old to&H9; learn, call not your stocks for&H4; me,
I serve the King, on&H4; whose employments I was sent to&H4; you,
You should do small respect, show too bold malice
Against the Grace and person of my master,
Stopping his messenger.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Fetch forth the stocks? as I have life and honour,
There shall he sit till noon.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Till noon, till night my Lord, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Why Madam, if I were your father's dog, you could
not use me so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sir being his knave, I will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: This is a fellow of the selfsame nature,
Our&Hrp; sister speak of, come bring away the stocks?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let me beseech your Grace not to&H9; do so&H52;,
His fault is much, and the good King his master
Will&H1; check him for&H4; it, your purposed low correction
Is such, as basest and contemnest wretches for&H4; pilferings
And most common trespasses are punished with,
The King must take it ill, that&H3; he is so&H51; slightly valued
In&H4; his messenger, should have him thus restrained.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I will&H1;. answer that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: My sister may receive it much more worse,
To&H9; have her&H2; Gentlemen abused, assaulted
For&H4; following her&H2; affairs, put in&H4; his legs,
Come my good Lord away?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am sorry for&H4; thee friend, it is the Duke's pleasure,
Whose disposition all the world well knows
Will&H1; not be rubbed nor stopped, I will&H1; entreat for&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Pray you do not sir, I have watched and travelled hard,
Sometime I shall sleep on&H4; it,the rest I will&H1; whistle,
A good man's fortune may grow out at heels,
Give you good morrow.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The Duke is to&H4; blame in&H4; this, it will&H1; be ill took.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good King that&H61; must approve the common saw,
Thou out of heaven's benediction comest
To&H4; the warm Sun.
Approach thou beacon to&H4; this under globe,
That&H3; by&H4; thy comfortable beams I may
Peruse this letter, nothing almost sees my wrack
But misery, I know it is from Cordelia,
Who&H61; hath most fortunately been informed
Of my obscured course, and shall find time
From this enormous state, seeking to&H9; give
Losses their remedies, all weary and overwatch
Take vantage heavy eyes not to&H9; behold
This shameful lodging, Fortune goodnight,
Smile, once more turn thy wheel.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I hear myself proclaimed,
And by&H4; the happy hollow of a tree
Escaped the hunt, no&H2; Port is free, no&H2; place
That&H61; guard, and most unusual vigilance
Dost not attend my taking while I may scape,
I will&H1; preserve myself, and am bethought
To&H9; take the basest and most poorest shape,
That&H61; ever penury in&H4; contempt of man,
Brought near to&H4; beast, my face I will&H1; grime with filth,
Blanket my loins, else all my hair with knots,
And with presented nakedness outface,
The wind, and persecution of the sky,
The Country gives me proof and president
Of Bedlam beggars, who&H61; with roaring voices,
Strike in&H4; their numbed and mortified bare arms,
Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary,
And with this horrible object from low service,
Poor pelting villages, sheepcotes,and miles,
Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers
Enforce their charity, poor Turlygod, poor Tom,
That&H62; is something yet, Edgar I nothing am.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: It is. strange that&H3; they should so&H52; depart from hence,
And not send back my messenger.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: As I learned, the night before there was
No&H2; purpose of his remove.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Hail to&H4; thee noble master.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: How, makest thou this shame thy pastime?

sp.speaker: Foolie.
sp.p:
Ha ha, look he wears cruel garters,
Horses are tied by&H4; the heels, dogs and bears
By&H4; the neck, monkeys by&H4; the loins, and men
By&H4; the legs, when a man is over lusty at legs,
Then he wears wooden netherstocks.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What is he, that&H61; hath so&H51; much thy place mistook to&H9; set
thee here?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: It is both he and she, your son and daughter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7; I say,

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I say yea.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7; no&H7;, they would not.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Yes they have.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: By&H4; Jupiter I swear no&H7;,they durst not do it,
They would not, could not do it, it is worse than murder,
To&H9; do upon&H4; respect such violent outrage,
Resolve me with all modest haste, which&H61; way
Thou mayst deserve, or they purpose this usage,
Coming from us&Hrp;.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My Lord, when at their home
I did commend your highness's letters to&H4; them,
Ere I was risen from the place that&H61; showed
My duty kneeling, came there a reeking Post,
Stewed in&H4; his haste, half breathless, panting forth
From Gonerill his mistress, salutations,
Delivered letters spite of intermission,
Which&H61; presently they read, on&H4; whose contents
They summoned up&H5; their men, straight took horse,
Commanded me to&H9; follow, and attend the leisure
Of their answer, gave me cold looks,
And meeting here the other messenger,
Whose welcome I perceived had poisoned mine,
Being the very fellow that&H61; of late
Displayed so&H51; saucily against your Highness,
Having more man than wit,about me drew,
He raised the house with loud and coward cries,
Your son and daughter found this trespass worth
This shame which&H61; here it suffers.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O how this mother swells up&H5; toward my heart,
Historica passio down thou climbing sorrow,
Thy element is below, where is this daughter?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: With the Earl sir within,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Follow me not, stay there?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Made you no&H2; more offence than what you speak of?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No&H7;, how chance the King comes with so&H51; small a train?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: if thou hadst been set in&H4; the stocks for&H4; that&H62; question, thou hadst well deserved it.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Why fool?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
We&Htp; will&H1; set thee to&H4; school to&H4; an Ant, to&H9; teach thee there is
no&H2; labouring in&H4; the winter, all that&H61; follow their noses, are led by&H4;
their eyes, but blind men, and there is not a nose among a hundred but
can smell him that&H61; is stinking, let go thy hold when a great
wheel runs down a hill, least it break thy neck with following it, but the great one that&H61; goes up&H4; the hill, let him draw thee
after, when a wise man gives thee better counsel, give me mine
again, I would have none but knaues follow it, since a fool
gives it.
sp.l: That&H62; Sir that&H61; serves for&H4; gain,
And follows but for&H4; form:
Will&H1; pack when it begin to&H9; rain,
And leave thee in&H4; the storm.
But I will&H1; tarry, the fool will&H1; stay,
And let the wise man fly:
The knave turns fool that&H61; runs away,
The fool no&H2; knave perdy.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Where learnt you this fool?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Not in&H4; the stocks.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Deny to&H9; speak with me, they are sick, they are weary,
They travelled hard tonight, mere Justice,
Aye the Images of revolt and flying off,
Fetch me a better answer.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: My dear Lord,
you know the fiery quality of the
Duke, how unremoveable and fixed he is in&H4; his own Course.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Vengeance, death, plague, confusion, what fiery quality,
why Gloster, Gloster, I would speak with the Duke of Cornewall, and
his wife.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The King would speak with Cornewal, the dear father
Would with his daughter speak, commands her&H2; service,
Fiery Duke, tell the hot Duke that&H3; Lear,
No&H7; but not yet may be he is not well,
Infirmity doth still neglect all office, where to&H4; our&Htp; health
Is bound, we&Htp; are not ourselves, when nature being oppressed
Command the mind to&H9; suffer with the body, I will&H1; forbear,
And am fallen out with my more headier will&H0;,
To&H9; take the indisposed and sickly fit, for&H3; the sound man,
Death on&H4; my state, wherefore should he sit here?
This act persuades me, that&H3; this remotion of the Duke, and her&H6;
Is practise,only give me my servant forth,
Tell the Duke and his wife, I will&H1;. speak with them
Now presently, bid them come forth and hear me,
Or at their chamber door I will&H1; beat the drum,
Till it cry sleep to&H4; death.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I would have all well betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O my heart, my heart.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Cry to&H4; it Nuncle, as the Cockney did to&H4; the eels, when
she put them in&H4; the paste alive, she rapt vm on&H4; the coxcombs with a stick,
and cried down wantons down, it was her&H2; brother,that&H61; in&H4; pure
kindness to&H4; his horse buttered his hay.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Good morrow to&H4; you both.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Hail to&H4; your Grace.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I am glad to&H9; see your highness.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Regan I think you are, I know what reason
I have to&H9; think so&H52;, if thou shouldst not be glad,
I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb
Sepulchring an adulteress, yea are you free?
Some other time for&H4; that&H62;. Beloved Regan,
Thy sister is naught, o Regan she hath tied,
Sharp-toothed unkindness, like&H4; a vulture here,
I can scarce speak to&H4; thee, thou wilt not believe,
Of how deprived a quality, O Regan.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I pray sir take patience, I have hope
You less know how to&H9; value her&H2; desert,
Than she to&H9; slack her&H2; duty.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: My curses on&H4; her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: O Sir you are old,
Nature on&H4; you stands on&H4; the very verge of her&H2; confine,
You should be ruled and led by&H4; some discretion,
That&H61; discerns your state better than you yourself,
Therefore I pray that&H3; to&H4; our&Hrp; sister,you do make return,
Say you have wronged her&H6; Sir?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ask her&H2; forgiveness,
Do you mark how this becomes the house,
Dear daughter, I confess that&H3; I am old,
Age is unnecessary, on&H4; my knees I beg,
That&H3; you will&H1; vouchsafe me raiment, bed and food.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Good sir no&H2; more, these are unsightly tricks,
Return you to&H4; my sister.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7; Regan,
She hath abated me of half my train,
Looked black upon&H4; me, struck me with her&H2; tongue
Most Serpent-like upon&H4; the very heart,
All the stored vengeances of heaven fall on&H4; her&H2; ingrateful top,
Strike her&H2; young bones,you taking airs with lameness.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Fie fie sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You nimble lightnings dart your blinding flames,
Into her&H2; scornful eyes, infect her&H2; beauty,
You fen-sucked fogs, drawn by&H4; the powerful Sun,
To&H9; fall and blast her&H2; pride.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: O the blessed Gods,so&H52; will&H1; you wish on&H4; me,
When the rash mood---

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7; Regan, thou shalt never have my curse,
The tender hefted nature shall not give thee over
To&H4; harshness, her&H2; eyes are fierce, but thine do comfort and not burn
It is. not in&H4; thee to&H9; grudge my pleasures, to&H9; cut off my train,
To&H9; bandy hasty words, to&H9; scant my sizes,
And in&H4; conclusion, to&H9; oppose the bolt
Against my coming in&H5;, thou better knowest,
The offices of nature, bond of child-hood,
Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude,
Thy half of the kingdom, hast thou not forgot
Wherein I thee endowed.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Good sir to&H4; the purpose.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Who&H62; put my man in&H4; the stocks?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: What trumpet is that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I know it my sister's, this approves her&H2; letters,
That&H3; she would soon be here, is your Lady come?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: This is a slave, whose easy borrowed pride
Dwells in&H4; the fickle grace of her&H6;, he follows,
Out varlet, from my sight.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: What means your Grace?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Who&H62; struck my servant, Regan I have good hope
Thou didst not know on&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Who&H62; comes here? O heavens!
If you do love old men, if you sweet sway allow
Obedience, if yourselves are old, make it your cause,
Send down and take my part,
Art not ashamed to&H9; look upon&H4; this beard?
O Regan wilt thou take her&H6; by&H4; the hand?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Why not by&H4; the hand sir, how have I offended?
All is not offence that&H61; indiscretion finds
And dotage terms so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O sides you are too tough,
Will&H1; you yet hold? how came my man in&H4; the stocks?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I set him there sir, but his own disorders
Deserved much less advancement,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You, did you?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I pray you father being weak seem so&H52;,
If till the expiration of your month,
You will&H1; return and sojourn with my sister,
Dismissing half your train, come then to&H4; me,
I am now from home, and out of that&H62; provision,
Which&H61; shall be needful for&H4; your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Return to&H4; her&H6;, and fifty men dismissed,
No&H7; rather I abjure all roofs, and choose
To&H9; wage against the enmity of the Air,
To&H9; be a Comrade with the Wolf and owl,
Necessity's sharpe pinch, return with her&H6;,
Why the hot blood in&H4; France, that&H61; dowerless
Took our&Hrp; youngest borne, I could as well be brought
To&H9; knee his throne,and Squire-like pension bag,
To&H9; keep base life afoot, return with her&H6;,
Persuade me rather to&H9; be slave and sumter
To&H4; this detested groom.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: At your choice sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Now I prithee daughter do not make me mad,
I will&H1; not trouble thee my child, farewell,
We&Htp; will&H1; no&H2; more meet, no&H2; more see one another.
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood,my daughter,
Or rather a disease that&H61; lies within my flesh,
Which&H61; I must needs call mine, thou art a bile,
A plague sore, an embossed carbuncle in&H4; my
Corrupted blood, but I will&H1;. not chide thee,
Let shame come when it will&H1;,I do not call it,
I do not bid the thunder bearer shoot,
Nor tell tails of thee to&H4; high Judging Jove,
Mend when thou canst, be better at thy leisure,
I can be patient, I can stay with Regan,
I and my hundred Knights.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Not altogether so&H52; sir, I look not for&H4; you yet,
Nor am provided for&H4; your fit welcome,
Give ear sir to&H4; my sister, for&H3; those
That&H61; mingle reason with your passion,
Must be content to&H9; think you are old, and so&H3;,
But she knows what she does.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Is this well spoken now?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I dare avouch it sir, what fifty followers,
Is it not well,what should you need of more,
Yea or so&H51; many, sith that&H3; both charge and danger
Speaks gainst so&H51; great a number, how in&H4; a house
Should many people under two commands
Hold amity, it is hard,almost impossible.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Why might not you my Lord receive attendance
From those that&H61; she calls servants, or from mine?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why not my Lord? if then they chancest to&H9; slack you,
We&Htp; could control them, if you will&H1; come to&H4; me,
For&H3; now I spy a danger, I entreat you,
To&H9; bring but five and twenty, to&H4; no&H2; more
Will&H1; I give place or notice.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I gave you all.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And in&H4; good time you gave it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Made you my guardians, my depositories,
But kept a reservation to&H9; be followed
With such a number, what, must I come to&H4; you
With five and twenty, Regan said you so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And speak it again my Lord, no&H2; more with me.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Those wicked creatures yet do seem well favoured
When others are more wicked, not being the worst
Stands in&H4; some rank of praise, I will&H1;. go with thee,
Thy fifty yet doth double five and twenty,
And thou art twice her&H2; love.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Hear me my Lord,
What need you five and twenty, ten, or five,
To&H9; follow in&H4; a house, where twice so&H51; many
Have a command to&H9; tend you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: What needs one?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O reason not the deed, our&Htp; basest beggars,
Are in&H4; the poorest thing superfluous,
Allow not nature more than nature needs,
Man's life as cheap as beasts, thou art a Lady,
If only to&H9; go warm were gorgeous,
Why nature needs not, what thou gorgeous wearest
Which&H61; scarcely keeps thee warm, but for&H4; true need,
You heavens give me that&H62; patience, patience I need,
You see me here (you Gods) a poor old fellow,
As full of grief as age, wretched in&H4; both,
If it be you that&H61; stirs these daughters' hearts
Against their Father, fool me not too much,
To&H9; bear it lamely, touch me with noble anger,
O let not women's weapons,water drops
Stain my man's cheeks, no&H7; you unnatural hags,
I will&H1; have such revenges on&H4; you both,
That&H3; all the world shall, I will&H1; do such things,
What they are yet I know not, but they shall be
The terrors of the earth, you think I will&H1; weep,
No&H7; I will&H1; not weep, I have full cause of weeping,
But this heart shall break,in&H4; a hundred thousand flaws
Or ere I will&H1; weep, O fool I shall go mad.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; withdraw, it will&H1; be a storm.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: This house is little the old man and his people,
Cannot be well bestowed.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: It is. his own blame hath put himself from rest,
And must needs taste his folly.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: For&H4; his particular, I will&H1; receive him gladly,
But not one follower.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: So&H52; am I purposed,where is my Lord of Gloster?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Followed the old man forth, he is returned.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The King is in&H4; high rage, and will&H1; I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It is. good to&H9; give him way, he leads himself.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My Lord, entreat him by&H4; no&H2; means to&H9; stay.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack the night comes on&H5;, and the bleak winds
Do sorely ruffle, for&H4; many miles about there is not a bush.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: O sir, to&H4; wilful men
The injuries that&H61; they themselves procure,
Must be their schoolmasters, shut up&H5; your doors,
He is attended with a desperate train,
And what they may incense him to&H5;, being apt,
To&H9; have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Shut up&H5; your doors my Lord,it is a wild night,
My Reg councils well,come out of the storm.

stage.l: Enter Kent and a Gentleman at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: What is here beside foul weather?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: One minded like&H4; the weather most unquietly.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I know you, where is the King?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Contending with the fretful element,
Bids the wind blow the earth into the sea,
Or swell the curled waters above the main
That&H3; things might change or cease, tears his white hair,
Which&H61; the impetuous blasts with eyeless rage
Catch in&H4; their fury, and make nothing of,
Strives in&H4; his little world of man to&H9; outscorn,
The to&H5; and fro conflicting wind and rain,
This night wherein the cub-drawn Bear would couch,
The Lion, and the belly pinched Wolf
Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs,
And bids what will&H1; take all.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: But who&H62; is with him?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: None but the fool, who&H61; labours to&H9; out-jest
