His heart struck injuries.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Sir I do know you,
And dare upon&H4; the warrant of my Art&H0;,
Commend a dear thing to&H4; you, there is division,
Although as yet the face of it be covered,
With mutual cunning, twixt Albany and Cornwall
But true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this scattered kingdom, who&H61; already wise in&H4; our&Htp; negligence,
Have secret feet in&H4; some of our&Htp; best Ports,
And are at point to&H9; show their open banner,
Now to&H4; you, if on&H4; my credit you dare build so&H51; far,
To&H9; make your speed to&H4; Douer, you shall find
Some that&H61; will&H1; thank you, making just report
Of how unnatural and bending sorrow
The King hath cause to&H9; plain,
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding,
And from some knowledge and assurance,
Offer this office to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will&H1; talk farther with you.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No&H7; do not,
For&H4; confirmation that&H3; I much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse and take
What it contains, if you shall see Cordelia,
As fear not but you shall, show her&H6; this ring,
And she will&H1; tell you who&H61; your fellow is,
That&H61; yet you do not know, fie on&H4; this storm,
I will&H1; go seek the King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Give me your hand, have you no&H2; more to&H9; say?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Few words but to&H9; effect more than all yet:
That&H3; when we&Htp; have found the King,
I will&H1;. this way,you that&H62;, he that&H61; first lights
On&H4; him, hollow the other.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Blow wind and crack your cheeks, rage, blow
You cataracts,and Hurricanes spout till you have drenched,
The steeples drowned the cocks, you sulphurous and
Thought executing fires, vaunt-currers to&H4;
Oak-cleaving thunderbolts, singe my white head,
And thou all shaking thunder, smite flat
The thick Rotundity of the world, crack nature's
Mould, all Germans spill at once that&H61; make
Ingrateful man.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
O Nuncle, Court holy water in&H4; a dry house
Is better than this rain water out-of-doors,
Good Nuncle in&H5;, and ask thy daughters blessing,
Here is a night pities nether wise man nor fool.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Rumble thy belly full, spit fire, spout rain,
Nor rain, wind,thunder, fire, are my daughters,
I task not you you elements with unkindness,
I never gave you kingdom, called you children,
You owe me no&H2; subscription, why then let fall your horrible pleasure
Here I stand your slave, a poor infirm weak and
Despised old man, but yet I call you servile
Ministers, that&H61; have with two pernicious daughters joined
Your high engendered battle gainst a head so&H51; old and white As this, O it is foul.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
He that&H61; has a house to&H9; put his head in&H5;, has a good
headpiece, the Codpiece that&H61; will&H1; house before the head, has
any the head and he shall louse, so&H52; beggars marry many, the
man that&H61; makes his toe, what he his heart should make, shall
have a corn cry woe, and turn his sleep to&H9; wake, for&H3;
there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths in&H4; a
glass.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7; I will&H1; be the pattern of all patience

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1; say nothing.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Who&H62; is there?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Marry here is Grace, and a codpiece, that&H62; is a wise man and a fool.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Alas sir, sit you here?
Things that&H61; love night, love not such nights as these,
The wrathful Skies gallow, the very wanderer of the
Dark, and makes them keep their caves,
Since I was man, such sheets of fire,
Such bursts of horrid thunder, such groans of
Roaring wind, and rain, I never remember
To&H9; have heard, man's nature cannot carry
The affliction, nor the force.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let the great Gods that&H61; keep this dreadful
Pother over our&Htp; heads, find out their enemies now,
Tremble thou wretch that&H61; hast within thee
undivulged crimes, unwhipped of Justice,
Hide thee thou bloody hand,thou perjured,and
Thou simular man of vertue that&H61; art incestuous,
Caitiff in&H4; pieces shake, that&H61; under covert
And convenient seeming, hast practised on&H4; man's life,
Close pent up&H5; guilts, rive your concealed centres,
And cry these dreadful summoners grace,
I am a man more sinned against their sinning.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Alack bare headed, gracious my Lord, hard by&H5; here is
a hovel, some friendship will&H1; it lend you gainst the tempest, repose you there, whilst I to&H4; this hard house, more hard than is
the stone whereof it is raised, which&H61; even but now demanding
after me, denied me to&H9; come in&H5;, return and force their scanted courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: My wit begins to&H9; turn,
Come on&H5; my boy, how dost my boy,art cold?
I am cold myself, where is this straw my fellow,
The art of our&Htp; necessities is strange that&H61; can,
Make vild things precious, come you hovel poor,
Fool and knave, I have one part of my heart
That&H61; sorrows yet for&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
He that&H61; has a little tine wit, with hey ho the wind
and the rain, must make content with his fortunes fit, for&H3; the
rain, it raineth every day.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: True my good boy, come bring us&Htp; to&H4; this hovel?

stage.l: Enter Gloster and the Bastard with lights.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack alack Edmund I like&H1; not this,
Unnatural dealing when I desired their leave
That&H3; I might pity him, they took me from me
The use of mine own house, charged me on&H4; pain
Of their displeasure, neither to&H9; speak of him,
Entreat for&H4; him,nor any way sustain him.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Most savage and unnatural.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
Go to&H5; say you nothing, there is a division betwixt the Dukes,
And a worse matter than that&H62;, I have received
A letter this night, it is dangerous to&H9; be spoken,
I have locked the letter in&H4; my closet, these injuries
The King now bears, will&H1; be revenged home
There is part of a power already landed,
We&Htp; must incline to&H4; the King, I will&H1; seek him,and
Privily relieve him, go you and maintain talk
With the Duke, that&H3; my charity be not of him
Perceived, if he ask for&H4; me, I am ill,and gon
To&H4; bed, though I die for&H4; it, as no&H2; less is threatened me,
The King my old master must be relieved, there is
Some strange thing toward, Edmund pray you be careful.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: This courtesy forbid thee, shall the Duke instantly know
And of that&H62; letter too, this seems a fair deserving
And must draw me that&H62; which&H61; my father looses, no&H2; less
Than all, then younger rises when the old do fall.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter, the
tyranny of the open night is too rough for&H4; nature to&H9; endure.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Wilt break my heart?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I had rather break mine own, good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thou thinkst it is much, that&H3; this tempestuous storm
Invades us&Htp; to&H4; the skin, so&H52; it is to&H4; thee,
But where the greater malady is fixed
The lesser is scarce felt, thou wouldst shun a Bear,
But if thy flight lay toward the roaring sea,
You wouldst meet the bear in&H4; the mouth, when the mind is free
The body is delicate, this tempest in&H4; my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats their filial ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For&H4; lifting food to&H4; it, but I will&H1; punish sure,
No&H7; I will&H1; weep no&H2; more, in&H4; such a night as this!
O Regan, Gonorill,your old kind father
Whose frank heart gave you all, O that&H62; way madness lies
Let me shun that&H62;, no&H2; more of that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Prithee go in&H5; thyself, seek thy one ease
This tempest will&H1; not give me leave to&H9; ponder
On&H4; things would hurt me more, but I will&H1; go in&H5;,
Poor naked wretches, wheresoever you are
That&H61; bide the pelting of this pitiless night,
How shall your house-less heads, and unfed sides,
Your looped and windowed raggedness defend you
From seasons such as these, O I have taken
Too little care of this, take physic pomp,
Expose thyself to&H9; feel what wretches feel,
That&H3; thou mayst shake the superflux to&H4; them,
And show the heavens more just.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p:
Come not in&H4; here Nuncle, here is a spirit, help me, help
me.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, who&H62; is there.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: A spirit, he says, his name is poor Tom.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: What art thou that&H61; dost grumble there in&H4; the straw,
come forth?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Away, the foul fiend follows me, thorough the sharpe
hawthorn blows the cold wind, go to&H4; thy cold bed and warm
thee.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Hast thou given all to&H4; thy two daughters, and art thou
come to&H4; this?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Who&H62; gives anything to&H4; poor Tom, whom the foul
Fiend hath led, through fire, and through ford, and
whirlpool, ore bog and quagmire, that&H61; has laid knives under his pillow, and halters in&H4; his pew, set ratsbane by&H4; his pottage,
made him proud of heart, to&H9; ride on&H4; a bay trotting horse over
four inched bridges, to&H9; course his own shadow for&H4; a traitor,
bless thy five wits, Tom is a cold, bless thee from whirlwinds,
star-blasting,and taking, do poor Tom some charity, whom
the foul fiend vexes, there could I have him now, and there, and
and there again.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What, his daughters brought him to&H4; this pass,
Couldst thou save nothing, didst thou give them all?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Nay he reserved a blanket, else we&Htp; had been all shamed.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Now all the plagues that&H61; in&H4; the pendulous air
Hang fated over men's faults, fall on&H4; thy daughters.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: He hath no&H2; daughters sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Death traitor, nothing could have subdued nature
To&H4; such a lowness, but his unkind daughters,
Is it the fashion that&H3; discarded fathers,
Should have thus little mercy on&H4; their flesh,
Judicious punishment it was this flesh
Begot those Pelican daughters.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Pilicock sate on&H4; pelicocks hill, a lo lo
lo.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: This cold night will&H1; turn us&Htp; all to&H4; fools and madmen.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Take heed of the foul fiend, obey thy parents, keep thy
words justly, swear not, commit not with man's sworn spouse,
set not thy sweet heart on&H4; proud array, Tom is a-cold,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
A Serving-man, proud in&H4; heart and mind, that&H61; curled my
hair, wore gloves in&H4; my cap, served the lust of my mistress heart,
and did the act of darkness with her&H6;, swore as many oaths as I
spake words, and broke them in&H4; the sweet face of heaven, one
that&H61; slept in&H4; the contriving of lust, and waked to&H9; do it, wine loved I deeply, dice dearly, and in&H4; woman out-paramoured the
Turk, false of heart, light of ear,bloody of hand, Hog in&H4; sloth,
Fox in&H4; stealth, Wolf in&H4; greediness,, Dog in&H4; madness, Lion
in&H4; prey, let not the creaking of shoes, nor the rustlngs of silks
betray thy poor heart to&H4; women, keep thy foot out of brothel, thy hand out of placket, thy pen from lender's book,
and defy the foul fiend, still through the hawthorn blows the
cold wind, hay no&H5; on&H5; ny, Dolphin my boy, my boy, cease
let him trot by&H5;.

sp.speaker: Lear.
Foole.
sp.p:
Prithee Nuncle be content, this is a naughty night to&H9;
swim in&H5;, now a little fire in&H4; a wild field, were like&H4; an old lecher's
heart, a small spark, all the rest in&H4; body cold, look here comes
a walking fire.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
This is the foul fiend flibbertigibbet, he begins at curfew, and walks till the first cock, he gives the web,and the pin,
squints the eye, and makes the hare lip, mildews the white
wheat, and hurts the poor creature of earth, swithald footed
thrice the old,he met the night mare and her&H2; nine fold bid her&H6;, O
light and her&H2; troth plight and aroint thee, witch aroint thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: How fares your Grace?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Who&H62; is there, what is it you seek?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What are you there? your names?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Poor Tom, that&H61; eats the swimming frog, the toad, the
tadpole, the wall-newt, and the water, that&H61; in&H4; the fury of his
heart, when the foul fiend rages, eats cow-dung for&H4; salads, swallows the old rat, and the ditch dog,drinks the green mantle of the standing poole, who&H61; is whipped from tithing to&H4; tithing,
and stock-punished and imprisoned, who&H61; hath had three suits to&H4;
his back, six shirts to&H4; his body, horse to&H9; ride, and weapon
to&H9; wear.
But mice and rats, and such small Dear,
Hath been Toms food for&H4; seven long year beware my follower, peace snulbug, peace thou fiend.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What hath your Grace no&H2; better company?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: The Prince of darkness is a Gentleman, modo he is called
and ma hu---

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Our&Htp; flesh and blood is grown so&H51; vild my Lord, that&H3; it
doth hate what gets it.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Poor Tom is a-cold.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Go in&H5; with me, my duty cannot suffer to&H9; obey in&H4; all your
daughter's hard commands, though their injunction be to&H9; bar
my doors, and let this tyrannous night take hold upon&H4; you, yet
have I ventured to&H9; come seek you out, and bring you where
both food and fire is ready.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: First let me talk with this Philosopher,
What is the cause of thunder?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My good Lord take his offer, go into the house.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1;. talk a word with this most learned Theban, what is
your study?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: How to&H9; prevent the fiend, and to&H9; kill vermin.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let me ask you one word in&H4; private.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Importune him to&H9; go my Lord, his wits begin to&H9; unsettle.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Canst thou blame him,
His daughters seek his death, O that&H62; good Kent,
He said it would be thus, poor banished man,
Thou sayst the King grows mad, I will&H1; tell thee friend
I am almost mad myself, I had a son
Now outlawed from my blood, he sought my life
But lately, very late, I loved him friend
No&H2; father his son dearer, true to&H9; tell thee,
The grief hath crazed my wits,
What a night is this? I do beseech your Grace.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O cry you mercy noble Philosopher, your company.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Tom is a-cold.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: In&H5; fellow there, in&H4; it hovel keep thee warm.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come let us&Htp; in&H5; all.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: This way my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: With him I will&H1; keep still, with my Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord sooth him, let him take the fellow.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Take him you on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Sirrah come on&H5;, go along with us&Htp;?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come good Athenian.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No&H2; words, no&H2; words, hush.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Child Rowland, to&H4; the dark town come,
His word was still fie fo and fum,
I smell the blood of a British man.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I will&H1; have my revenge ere I depart the house.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
How my Lord I may be censured, that&H3; nature thus gives
way to&H4; loyalty, something fears me to&H9; think of.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
I now perceive it was not altogether your brother's evil disposition made him seek his death, but a provoking merit,
set a-work by&H4; a reprovable badness in&H4; himself.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
How malicious is my fortune, that&H3; I must repent to&H9; be
just? this is the letter he spoke of, which&H61; approves him an intelligent party to&H4; the advantages of France, O heavens that&H3; his treason were, or not I the detector.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Go with me to&H4; the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty
business in&H4; hand.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloster, seek
out where thy father is, that&H3; he may be ready for&H4; our&Hrp; apprehension.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If I find him comforting the King, it will&H1; stuff his suspicion more fully, I will&H1; persevere in&H4; my course of loyalty,
though the conflict be sore between that&H62; and my blood.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
I will&H1; lay trust upon&H4; thee, and thou shalt find a dearer
father in&H4; my love.

stage.l: Enter Gloster and Lear, Kent, Foole, and Tom.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
Here is better than the open air, take it thankfully, I
will&H1; piece out the comfort with what addition I can, I will&H1; not be
long from you.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
All the power of his wits have given way to&H4; impatience,
the Gods deserve your kindness.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Fretereto calls me, and tells me Nero is an angler in&H4; the
lake of darkness, pray innocent beware the foul fiend.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Prithee Nuncle tell me, whether a mad man be a Gentleman or a Yeoman.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
A King, a King, to&H9; have a thousand with red burning
spits come hissing in&H5; upon&H4; them.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: The foul fiend bites my back,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: He is mad, that&H61; trusts in&H4; the tameness of a Wolf, a horse's health, a boy's love, or a whore's oath.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: It shall be done, I will&H1; arraign them straight,
Come sit thou here most learned Justice
Thou sapient sir sit here, no&H7; you she Foxes--

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Look where he stands and glares, wantest thou eyes, at
trial madam come over the broom Bessy to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Her&H2; boat hath a leak, and she must not speak,
Why she dares not come, over to&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in&H4; the voice of a nightingale,
Hoppedance cries in&H4; Toms belly for&H4; two white herring,
Croak not black Angel, I have no&H2; food for&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: How do you sir? stand you not so&H51; amazed, will&H1; you
lie down and rest upon&H4; the cushions?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1;. see their trial first, bring in&H5; their evidence, thou
robed man of Justice take thy place, and thou his yoke-fellow of
equity, bench by&H4; his side, you are of the commission, sit you too.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; deal justly sleepest or wakest thou jolly shepherd,
Thy sheep be in&H4; the corn, and for&H4; one blast of thy minikin
mouth, thy sheep shall take no&H2; harm, Purr the cat is gray.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Arraign her&H6; first it is Gonoril, I here take my oath before
this honourable assembly kicked the poor king her&H2; father.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Come hither mistress is your name Gonorill.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: She cannot deny it.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.p: Cry you mercy I took you for&H4; a join stool.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And here is another whose warped looks proclaim,
What store her&H2; hart is made of, stop her&H6; there,
Arms,arms, sword, fire, corruption in&H4; the place,
False Justicer why hast thou let her&H6; scape.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Bless thy five wits.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: O pity sir, where is the patience now,
That&H61; you so&H51; oft have boasted to&H9; retain.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: My tears begin to&H9; take his part so&H51; much,
They will&H1; mar my counterfeiting.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The little dogs and all
Trey, Blanch, and Sweetheart,see they bark at me.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Tom will&H1; throw his head at them,avaunt you curs,
Be thy mouth, or black, or white, tooth that&H61; poisons if it bite,
Mastiff, greyhound, mongrel, grim-hound or spaniel, brach or him,
Bobtail tike, or trundletail, Tom will&H1; make them weep and wail,
For&H3; with throwing thus my head, dogs leap the hatch and all
are fled, loudla doodla come march to&H4; wakes, and fairs, and
market towns, poor Tom thy horn is dry.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Then let them anatomise Regan, see what breeds about her&H2;
Heart is there any cause in&H4; nature that&H61; makes this hardness,
You sir, I entertain you for&H4; one of my hundred,
Only I do not like&H1; the fashion of your garments you will&H1; say,
They are Persian attire, but let them be changed.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Now good my Lord lie here awhile.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Make no&H2; noise, make no&H2; noise, draw the curtains, so&H3;, so&H3;, so&H3;,
We&Htp; will&H1; go to&H4; supper in&H4; the morning, so&H3;, so&H3;, so&H3;,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Come hither friend, where is the King my master.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Here sir, but trouble him not his wits are gon.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good friend I prithee take him in&H4; thy arms,
I have overheard a plot of death upon&H4; him,
There is a Litter ready lay him in&H4; it,and drive towards Douer friend,
Where thou shalt meet both welcome and protection, take up&H5; thy master,
If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life with thine
And all that&H61; offer to&H9; defend him stand in&H4; assured loss,
Take up&H5; the King and follow me, that&H61; will&H1; to&H4; some provision
Give thee quick conduct.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Oppressed nature sleeps,
This rest might yet have balmed thy broken sinews,
Which&H61; if convenience will&H1; not allow stand in&H4; hard cure,
Come help to&H9; bear thy master, thou must not stay behind.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Come, come away.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: When we&Htp; our&Htp; betters see bearing our&Htp; woes: we&Htp; scarcely
think, our&Htp; miseries, our&Htp; foes.
Who&H61; alone suffers suffers, most in&H4; the mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind,
But then the mind much sufferance doth over-skip,
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship:
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that&H62; which&H61; makes me bend, makes the King bow.
He childed as I fathered, Tom away,
Mark the high noises and thyself bewray,
When false opinion whose wrong thoughts defile thee,
In&H4; thy just proof repeals and reconciles thee,
What will&H1; hap more tonight, safe scape the King,
Lurk, lurk.

stage.l: Enter Cornwall, and Regan, and Gonorill, and Bastard.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Post speedily to&H4; my Lord your husband show him this letter
The army of France is landed, seek out the villain Gloster.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Hang him instantly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Pluck out his eyes.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Leave him to&H4; my displeasure, Edmund keep you our&Hrp; sister company.
sp.p:
The revenge we&Hrp; are bound to&H9; take upon&H4; your traitorous father,
Are not fit for&H4; your beholding, advise the Duke where you are going
To&H4; a most festinate preparation we&Hrp; are bound to&H4; the like&H2;,
Our&Htp; post shall be swift and intelligence betwixt us&Htp;,
sp.l: Farewell dear sister, farewell my Lord of Gloster,
How now where is the King?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: My Lord of Gloster hath conveyed him hence,
Some five or six and thirty of his Knights hot questrists after
him, met him at gate, who&H61; with some other of the Lord's dependants are gone with him towards Douer, where they boast to&H9;
have well armed friends.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Get horses for&H4; your mistress.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Lord and sister.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Edmund farewell. go seek the traitor Gloster.
Pinion him like&H4; a thief, bring him before us&Hrp;,
Though we&Hrp; may not pass upon&H4; his life
Without the form of Justice, yet our&Hrp; power
Shall do a courtesy to&H4; our&Hrp; wrath, which&H61; men may blame
But not control, who&H62; is there, the traitor?

stage.l: Enter Gloster brought in by two or three,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Ingrateful Fox it is he.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bind fast his corky arms.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What means your Graces, good my friends consider,
You are my guests, do me no&H2; foul play friends.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bind him I say,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Hard hard, O filthy traitor!

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Unmerciful Lady as you are, I am true.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: To&H4; this chair bind him, villain thou shalt find---

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: By&H4; the kind Gods it is most ignobly done, to&H9; pluck me
by&H4; the beard.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: So&H51; white and such a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Naughty Lady, these hairs which&H61; thou dost ravish from my chin
Will&H1; quicken and accuse thee, I am your host.
With robber's hands, my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus, what will&H1; you do.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Come sir, what letters had you late from France?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Be simple insurer, for&H3; we&Htp; know the truth.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: And what confederacy have you with the traitors late
footed in&H4; the kingdom?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: To&H4; whose hands you have sent the lunatic King speak?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I have a letter guessingly set down
Which&H61; came from one, that&H61; is of a neutral heart,
And not from one opposed.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Cunning.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And false.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Where hast thou sent the King?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To&H4; Douer.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Wherefore to&H4; Douer? wast thou not charged at perill---

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Wherefore to&H4; Douer? let him first answer that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am tide to&H4; the stake, and I must stand the course.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Wherefore to&H4; Douer sir?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister
In&H4; his anointed flesh rash boorish fangs,
The Sea with such a storm of his loved head
In&H4; hell black night endured, would have laid up&H5;
And quenched the steeled fires, yet poor old heart,
He helped the heavens to&H9; rage,
If wolves had at thy gate heard that&H62; stern time
Thou shouldst have said, good Porter turn the key,
All cruels else subscribed but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: See it shalt thou never, fellows hold the chair,
Upon&H4; those eyes of thine, I will&H1;. set my foot.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He that&H61; will&H1; think to&H9; live till he be old
Give me some help, O cruel, O ye Gods!

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: One side will&H1; mock another,the other too.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: If you see vengeance---

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: Hold your hand my Lord
I have served ever since I was a child
But better service have I never done you, than now to&H9; bid you hold.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: How now you dog.

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: If you did wear a beard upon&H4; your chin I would shake it
on&H4; this quarrel,what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My villain.

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: Why then come on&H5;,and take the chance of anger.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Give me thy sword, a peasant stand up&H5; thus.

stage.l: Shee takes a sword and runs at him behind.

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: O I am slain my Lord, yet have you one eye left to&H9;
see some mischief on&H4; him, o !

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Lest it see more prevent it, out vild Jelly.
Where is thy luster now?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: All dark and comfortless, where is my son Edmund?
Edmund unbridled all the sparks of nature, to&H9; quit this horrid act.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Out villain, thou callest on&H4; him that&H61; hates thee, it was he
sp.p:
that&H61; made the overture of thy treasons to&H4; us&Htp;, who&H61; is too good to&H9;
pity thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O my follies, then Edgar was abused,
Kind Gods forgive me that&H62;,and prosper him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell his way to&H4;
Douer, how is it my Lord? how look you?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I have received a hurt, follow me Lady,
Turn out that&H62; eyeless villain, throw this slave upon&H4;
The dunghill Regan, I bleed apace,untimely
Comes this hurt, give me your arm.

sp.speaker: Ser 2.
sp.l: I will&H1;. never care what wickedness I do,
If this man come to&H4; good.

sp.speaker: Ser 3.
sp.l: If she live long, and in&H4; the end meet the old course
of death, women will&H1; all turn monsters.

sp.speaker: Ser 2.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; follow the old Earl, and get the bedlam
To&H9; lead him where he would, his madness
Allows itself to&H4; anything.

sp.speaker: Ser 3.
sp.l: Go thou, I will&H1; fetch some flax and whites of eggs to&H9;
apply to&H4; his bleeding face, now heaven help him.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Yet better thus, and known to&H9; be contemned,
Than still contemned and flattered to&H9; be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of Fortune
Stands still in&H4; experience, lives not in&H4; fear,
The lamentable change is from the best,
The worst returns to&H4; laughter,
Who&H62; is here, my father party-eyed, world, world, O world!
But that&H3; thy strange mutations make us&Htp; hate thee,
Life would not yield to&H4; age.

stage.l: Enter Glost. led by an old man.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: O my good Lord, I have been your tenant,and your
father's tenant this forescore---

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Away, get thee away, good friend be gon,
Thy comforts can do me no&H2; good at all,
Thee they may hurt.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Alack sir, you cannot see your way.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I have no&H2; way, and therefore want no&H2; eyes,
I stumbled when I saw, full oft it is seen
Our&Htp; means secure us&Htp;, and our&Htp; mere defects
Prove our&Htp; commodities, ah dear son Edgar,
The food of thy abused father's wrath,
Might I but live to&H9; see thee in&H4; my touch,
I would say I had eyes again.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: How now who&H62; is there?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O Gods, who&H62; is it can say I am at the worst,
I am worse than ever I was.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: It is. poor mad Tom.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: And worse I may be yet, the worst is not.
As long as we&Htp; can say, this is the worst.

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Fellow where goest?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Is it a beggar man?

sp.speaker: Old man.
sp.l: Mad man, and beggar too.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He has some reason, else he could not beg,
In&H4; the last night's storm I such a fellow saw,
Which&H61; made me think a man a worm,my son
Came then into my mind, and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him, I have heard more since,
As flies are to&H4; the wanton boys,are we&Htp; to&H4; the Gods,
They bitt us&Htp; for&H4; their sport.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: How should this be, bad is the trade that&H61; must play the
fool to&H4; sorrow angering itself and others, bless thee master.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Is that&H62; the naked fellow?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Aye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then prithee get thee gon, if for&H4; my sake
Thou wilt overtake us&Htp; here a mile or twain
In&H4; the way toward Douer, do it for&H4; ancient love
And bring some covering for&H4; this naked soul
Who&H61; I will&H1;. entreat to&H9; lead me.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Alack sir he is mad.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is. the time's plague, when madmen lead the blind,
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure,
Above the rest, be gon.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I will&H1;. bring him the best apparel that&H61; I have
Come on&H4; it what will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sirrah naked fellow.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Poor Tom is a-cold, I cannot dance it farther.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Come hither fellow.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Knowest thou the way to&H4; Douer?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Both style and gate, horse-way, and foot-path,
Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits,
Bless the good man from the foul fiend,
Five fiends have been in&H4; poor Tom at once,
Of lust, as Obidicut, Hobbididence Prince of dumbness,
Mahu of stealing, Modo of murder, Stiberdigebit of
Mobing, and Mobing who&H61; since possesses chambermaids
And waiting women, so&H3;, bless thee master.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here take this purse, thou whom the heavens plagues.
Have humbled to&H4; all strokes, that&H3; I am wretched, makes thee
The happier, heavens deal so&H52; still,
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man
That&H61; stands your ordinance, that&H61; will&H1; not see
Because he does not feel,feel your power quickly,
So&H52; distribution should under excess,
And each man have enough, dost thou know Douer?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Aye master.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: There is a cliff whose high and bending head
Looks firmly in&H4; the confined deep,
Bring me but to&H4; the very brim of it
And I will&H1; repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me,
From that&H62; place I shall no&H2; leading need.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me thy arm, poor Tom shall lead thee.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord, I marvel our&Hrp; mild husband
Not met us&Hrp; on&H4; the way, now where is your master?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.p:
Madam within, but never man so&H51; changed, I told him
of the army that&H61; was landed, he smiled at it, I told him you were
coming, his answer was the worse, of Glosters treachery, and of
the loyal service of his son when I informed him, then he
called me sot, and told me I had turned the wrong side out, what
he should most desire seems pleasant to&H4; him, what like&H1; offensive.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Then shall you go no&H2; further,
It is the cowish terror of his spirit
That&H61; dares not undertake, he will&H1; not feel wrongs
Which&H61; tie him to&H4; an answer, our&Htp; wishes on&H4; the way
May prove effects, back Edgar to&H4; my brother,
Hasten his musters, and conduct his powers
I must change arms at home,and give the distaff
Into my husband's hands, this trusty servant
Shall pass between us&Htp;, ere long you are like&H5; to&H9; hear
If you dare venture in&H4; your own behalf
A mistress's command, wear this, spare speech,
Decline your head: this kiss if it durst speak
Would stretch thy spirits up&H5; into the air,
Conceive and far you well.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Yours in&H4; the ranks of death.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My most dear Gloster, to&H4; thee woman's services are dew
A fool usurps my bed.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam here comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I have been worth the whistling.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O Gonoril,you are not worth the dust which&H61; the rude wind
Blows in&H4; your face, I fear your disposition
That&H62; nature which&H61; contemns in&H4; the origin
Cannot be bordered certain in&H4; itself,
She that&H61; herself will&H1; sliver and disbranch
From her&H2; material sap, perforce must wither,
And come to&H4; deadly use.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: No&H2; more, the text is foolish.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Wisdom and goodness, to&H4; the vild seem vild,
Filth's savour but themselves, what have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you performed?
A father, and a gracious aged man
Whose reverence even the head-lugged bear would lick.
Most barbarous, most degenerate have you madded,
Could my good brother suffer you to&H9; do it?
A man, a Prince, by&H4; him so&H51; benefited,
If that&H3; the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to&H9; tame the vild offences, it will&H1; come
Humanity must perforce pray on&H4; itself like&H4; monsters of the deep.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Milk-livered man
That&H61; bearest a cheek for&H4; blows, a head for&H4; wrongs,
Who&H61; hast not in&H4; thy brows an eye deserving thine honour,
From thy suffering, that&H61; not knowest, fools do those villains pity
Who&H61; are punished ere they have done their mischief,
Where is thy drum? France spreads his banners in&H4; our&Htp; noiseless land,
With plumed helm, thy state begin thereat
Whilst thou a moral fool sits still and cries
Alack why does he so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: See thyself devil, proper deformity shows not in&H4; the
fiend, so&H51; horrid as in&H4; woman.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: O vain fool!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Thou changed, and self-covered thing for&H4; shame
Be-monster not thy feature, were it my fitness
To&H9; let these hands obey my blood,
They are apt enough to&H9; dislocate and tear
Thy flesh and bones, however thou art a fiend,
A woman's shape doth shield thee.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Marry your manhood mew---

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What news.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O my good Lord the Duke of Cornwall is dead, slain by&H4;
his servant, going to&H9; put out the other eye of Gloster.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Glosters eyes?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A servant that&H61; he bred, thralled with remorse,
Opposed against the act, bending his sword
To&H4; his great master, who&H61; thereat enraged
Flew on&H4; him, and amongst them, field him dead,
But not without that&H62; harmful stroke, which&H61; since
Hath plucked him after.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This shows you are above you Justicers,
That&H61; these our&Htp; nether crimes so&H51; speedily can venge.
But O poor Gloster lost he his other eye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Both, both my Lord, this letter Madam craves a speedy answer,
It is. from your sister.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: One way I like&H1; this well,
But being widow and my Gloster with her&H6;,
May all the building on&H4; my fancy pluck,
Upon&H4; my hateful life, another way the news is not so&H51; took,
I will&H1;. read and answer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where was his son when they did take his eyes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come with my Lady hither.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No&H7; my good Lord I met him back again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Knows he the wickedness.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord it was he informed against him,
And quit the house on&H4; purpose that&H3; there punishment
Might have the freer course.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Gloster I live to&H9; thank thee for&H4; the love thou showedst the King,
And to&H9; revenge thy eyes, come hither friend,
Tell me what more thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
Why the King of France is so&H51; suddenly gone back,
know you no&H2; reason.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Something he left imperfect in&H4; the state, which&H61; since his
coming forth is thought of, which&H61; imports to&H4; the Kingdom,
So&H51; much fear and danger that&H3; his personal return was most required and necessary.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Who&H62; hath he left behind him, General.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The Marshall of France Monsieur la Far.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p: Did your letters pierce the queen to&H4; any demonstration of grief.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I say she took them, read them in&H4; my presence,
And now and then an ample tear trilled down
Her&H2; delicate cheek, it seemed she was a queen over her&H2; passion,
Who&H61; most rebel-like, sought to&H9; be King over her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: O then it moved her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not to&H4; a rage, patience and sorrow stream,
Who&H61; should express her&H6; goodliest you have seen,
Sun shine and rain at once, her&H2; smiles and tears,
Were like&H4; a better way those happy smilets,
That&H61; played on&H4; her&H2; ripe lip seem not to&H9; know,
What guests were in&H4; her&H2; eyes which&H61; parted thence,
As pearls from diamonds dropped in&H4; brief,
Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved,
If all could so&H51; become it.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Made she no&H2; verbal question.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Faith once or twice she heaved the name of father,
Pantingly forth as if it pressed her&H2; heart,
Cried sisters, sisters, shame of Ladies sisters:
Kent, father, sisters, what in&H4; the storm in&H4; the night,
Let pity not be believe it there she shook,
The holy water from her&H2; heavenly eyes,
And clamour moistened her&H6;, then away she started,
To&H9; deal with grief alone.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: It is the stars, the stars above us&Htp; govern our&Htp; conditions,
Else one self mate and make could not beget,
Such different issues, you spoke not with her&H6; since.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Was this before the King returned.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No&H7;, since.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Well sir, the poor distressed Lear is in&H4; the town,
Who&H61; some time in&H4; his better tune remembers,
What we&Htp; are come about, and by&H4; no&H2; means will&H1; yield to&H9; see his daughter.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why good sir?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: A sovereign shame so&H51; elbows him his own unkindness
That&H61; stripped her&H6; from his benediction turned her&H6;,
To&H4; foreign casualties gave her&H2; dear rights,
To&H4; his dog-hearted daughters, these things sting his mind,
So&H51; venomously that&H3; burning shame detains him from Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Alack poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Of Albanies and Cornewals powers you heard not.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is so&H52; they are a-foot.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Well sir, I will&H1; bring you to&H4; our&Htp; master Lear,
And leave you to&H9; attend him some dear cause,
Will&H1; in&H4; concealment wrap me up&H5; awhile,
When I am known aright you shall not grieve,
Lending me this acquaintance, I pray you go along with me.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Alack it is he, why he was met even now,
As mad as the vent sea singing aloud,
Crowned with rank femiter and furrow weeds,
With hor-docks, hemlock,nettles, cuckoo flowers,
Darnel and all the idle weeds that&H61; grow,
In&H4; our&Htp; sustaining, corn, a century is sent forth,
Search every acre in&H4; the hie grown field,
And bring him to&H4; our&Hrp; eye, what can man's wisdom
In&H4; the restoring his bereaved sense, he that&H61; can help him
Take all my outward worth.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: There is means Madam.
Our&Htp; foster nurse of nature is repose,
The which&H61; he lacks that&H62; to&H9; provoke in&H4; him,
Are many simples operative whose power,
Will&H1; close the eye of anguish.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: All blessed secrets all you unpublished virtues of the earth,
Spring with my tears be aidant and remediate,
In&H4; the good man's distress, seek,seek,for&H4; him,
Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life.
That&H61; wants the means to&H9; lead it.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: News Madam, the British powers are marching hitherward.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: It is. known before, our&Htp; preparation stands,
In&H4; expectation of them, o dear father
It is thy business that&H61; I go about, therefore great France
My mourning and important tears hath pitied,
No&H2; blown ambition doth our&Htp; arms in&H4; sight
But love, dear love, and our&Hrp; aged father's right,
Soon may I hear and see him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: But are my brother's powers set forth?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Aye Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Himself in&H4; person?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam with much ado,your sister is the better soldier.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Lord Edmund spake not with your Lady at home.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: No&H7; Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: What might import my sister's letters to&H4; him?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I know not Lady.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Faith he is posted hence on&H4; serious matter,
It was great ignorance, Glosters eyes being out
To&H9; let him live, where he arrives he moves
All hearts against us&Htp;, and now I think is gone
In&H4; pity of his misery to&H9; dispatch his benighted life,
Moreover to&H9; descry the strength of the army.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I must needs after him with my letters

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Our&Htp; troop sets forth tomorrow stay with us&Htp;,
The ways are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I may not Madam, my Lady charged my duty in&H4; this
business.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why should she write to&H4; Edmund? might not you
Transport her&H2; purposes by&H4; word, belike
Something, I know not what, I will&H1; love thee much,
Let me unseal the letter.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam I would rather---

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I know your Lady does not love her&H2; husband
I am sure of that&H62;, and at her&H2; late being here
She gave strange oeliads, and most speaking looks
To&H4; noble Edmund, I know you are of her&H2; bosom.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Aye Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I speak in&H4; understanding, for&H3; I know it,
Therefore I do advise you take this note,
My Lord is dead, Edmund and I have talked,
And more convenient is he for&H4; my hand
Than for&H4; your Ladies, you may gather more
If you do find him, pray you give him this,
And when your mistress hears thus much from you
I pray desire her&H6; call her&H2; wisdom to&H4; her&H6;, so&H3; farewell,
If you do chance to&H9; hear of that&H62; blind traitor,
Preferment falls on&H4; him that&H61; cuts him off.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Would I could meet him Madam, I would show
What Lady I do follow.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: When shall we&Htp; come to&H4; the top of that&H62; same hill?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: You do climb it up&H5; now, look how we&Htp; labour?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Methinks the ground is even.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Horrible steep, hark do you hear the sea?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No&H7; truly.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Why then your other senses grow imperfect
By&H4; your eyes anguish.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: So&H52; may it be indeed,
Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speakest
With better phrase and matter than thou didst.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: you are much deceived, in&H4; nothing am I changed
But in&H4; my garments.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Methinks you are better spoken.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Come on&H5; sir, here is the place, stand still, how fearful
And dizzy it is to&H9; cast ones eyes so&H51; low
The crows and choughs that&H61; wing the midway air
Show scarce so&H51; gross as beetles, half way down
Hangs one that&H61; gathers samphire, dreadful trade,
Methinks he seems no&H2; bigger than his head,
The fishermen that&H61; walk upon&H4; the beach
Appear like&H4; mice,and yon tall anchoring bark
Diminished to&H4; her&H2; cock, her&H2; cock a buoy
Almost too small for&H4; sight, the murmuring surge
That&H61; on&H4; the unnumbered idle pebble chafes
Cannot be heard, it is so&H51; hie I will&H1; look no&H2; more,
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Set me where you stand?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me your hand, you are now within a foot
Of the extreme verge, for&H4; all beneath the Moon
Would I not leap upright.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let go my hand,
Here friend is another purse, in&H4; it a jewel,
Well worth a poor man's taking, Fairies and Gods
Prosper it with thee, go thou farther off,
Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Now fare you well good sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Why I do trifle thus with his despair is done to&H9; cure it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O you mighty Gods,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This world I do renounce, and in&H4; your sights
Shake patiently my great affliction off,
If I could bear it longer and not fall
To&H9; quarrel with your great opposeless wills
My snuff and loathed part of nature should
Burn itself out, if Edgar live, O bless,
Now fellow fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Gon sir, farewell, and yet I know not how conceit may
rob the treasury of life, when life itself yields to&H4; the theft,
alive or dead, ho you sir, hear you sir, speak,thus might he pass
indeed, yet he revives, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Away and let me die.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Hadst thou been aught but gossamer feathers air,
So&H51; many fathom down precipitating
Thou hadst shivered like&H4; an egg, but thou dost breath
Hast heavy substance, bleedest not, speakest, art sound,
Ten masts at each, make not the altitude,
Which&H61; thou hast perpendicularly fell,
Thy life is a miracle,speak yet again.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But have I fallen or no&H5;

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: From the dread summit of this chalky borne,
Look up&H5; a-height, the shrill gorged lark so&H51; far
Cannot be seen or heard, do but look up&H5;?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack I have no&H2; eyes
Is wretchedness deprived, that&H62; benefit
To&H9; end itself by&H4; death it was yet some comfort
When misery could beguile the tyrant's rage
And frustrate his proud will&H0;.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me your arm?
Up&H5;, so&H3;, how feel you your legs, you stand.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Too well, too well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: This is above all strangeness
Upon&H4; the crown of the cliff what thing was that&H62;
Which&H61; parted from you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A poor unfortunate beggar.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: As I stood here below methoughts his eyes
Were two full Moons, he had a thousand noses
Horns, whelked and waved like&H4; the enridged sea,
It was some fiend, therefore thou happy father
Think that&H3; the clearest Gods, who&H61; made their honours
Of men's impossibilities, have preserved thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I do remember now, henceforth I will&H1; bear
Affliction till it do cry out itself
Enough, enough,and die that&H62; thing you speak of,
I took it for&H4; a man, often would it say
The fiend the fiend,he led me to&H4; that&H62; place

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Bare free and patient thoughts, but who&H62; comes here
The safer sense will&H1; never accommodate his master thus.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7; they cannot touch me for&H4; coining, I am the king himself.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O thou side-piercing sight.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Nature is above Art&H0; in&H4; that&H62; respect, there is your press
money, that&H62; fellow handles his bow like&H4; a crow-keeper, draw me
a clothier's yard, look, look a mouse, peace, peace, this toasted
cheese will&H1; do it, there is my gauntlet, I will&H1; prove it on&H4; a giant,bring
up&H5; the brown-bills, O well flown bird in&H4; the air, ha, give
the word?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Sweet Marjoram.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Pass.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know that&H62; voice.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Ha Gonorill, ha Regan, they flattered me like&H4; a dog,
and told me I had white hairs in&H4; my beard, ere the black ones
were there, to&H9; say aye and no&H7;,to&H4; everything I said, aye and no&H7; too,
was no&H2; good divinity, when the rain came to&H9; wet me once, and
the wind to&H9; make me chatter, when the thunder would not
peace at my bidding, there I found them,there I smelt them out,
go to&H5;, they are not men of their words, they told me I was
everything, it is a lie, I am not ague-proof.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The trick of that&H62; voice I do well remember, is it not
the King?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Aye every inch a King when I do stare, see how the subject
quakes, I pardon that&H62; man's life, what was thy cause, adultery?
thou shalt not die for&H4; adultery, no&H7; the wren goes to&H4; it, and the
small gilded fly do lecher in&H4; my sight, let copulation thrive,
for&H3; Glosters bastard son was kinder to&H4; his father than my daughters got tween the lawful sheets, to&H4; it luxury, pell, mell, for&H3; I
lack soldiers, behold yon simpering dame whose face between
her&H2; forks presageth snow, that&H61; minces vertue, and do shake the
head hear of pleasure's name to&H4; fitchew nor the soiled horse
goes to&H4; it with a more riotous appetite, down from the wast they are
centaurs, though women all above, but to&H4; the girdle do the
gods inherit, beneath is all the fiend's, there is hell, there is darkness,
there is the sulphury pit, burning, scalding, stench, consummation,
fie, fie, fie, pah, pah, Give me an ounce of Civet, good Apothecary, to&H9; sweeten my imagination, there is money for&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O let me kiss that&H62; hand.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Here wipe it first, it smells of mortality.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O ruined piece of nature, this great world should so&H52;
wear out to&H4; naught, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Lear.
Glo.
sp.l: Were all the letters suns I could not see one.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I would not take this from report, it is, and my heart
breaks at it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Read.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What! with the case of eyes

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
O ho, are you there with me, no&H2; eyes in&H4; your head, nor no&H2; money in&H4; your purse, your eyes are in&H4; a heavy case, your purse
in&H4; a light, yet you see how this world goes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I see it feelingly.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
What art mad, a man may see how the world goes with
no&H2; eyes, look with thy ears, see how yon Justice rails upon&H4;
yon simple thief, hark in&H4; thy ear handy, dandy, which&H62; is the
thief, which&H62; is the Justice, thou hast seen a farmer's dog bark
at a beggar.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
And the creature run from the cur, there thou mightst
behold the great image of authority, a dog, so&H52; bade in&H4; office,
thou rascal beadle hold thy bloody hand, why dost thou lash
that&H62; whore, strip thine own back, thy blood hotly lusts to&H9; use
her&H6; in&H4; that&H62; kind for&H4; which&H61; thou whipst her&H6;, the usurer hangs the
cozener, through tottered rags, small vices do appear, robes and
furred-gowns hides all, get thee glass eyes, and like&H4; a scurvy politician seem to&H9; see the things thou doest not, no&H7; now pull off
my boots, harder, harder,so&H3;.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O matter and impertinency mixed reason in&H4; madness.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: If thou wilt weep my fortune take my eyes, I know
thee well enough thy name is Gloster, thou must be patient, we&Htp;
came crying hither, thou knowest the first time that&H61; we&Htp; smell the
air, we&Htp; wail and cry, I will&H1; preach to&H4; thee mark me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack alack the day.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: When we&Htp; are borne, we&Htp; cry that&H3; we&Htp; are come to&H4; this
great stage of fools, this a good blocke. It were a delicate stratagem to&H9; shoot a troupe of horse with fell,and when I have stole
upon&H4; these son-in-laws, then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O here he is, lay hands upon&H4; him sirs, your most dear

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H2; rescue, what a prisoner, I am even the natural fool
of Fortune, use me well you shall have ransom, let me have a
surgeon I am cut to&H4; the brains.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You shall have anything.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H2; seconds, all myself, why this would make a man
of salt to&H9; use his eyes for&H4; garden waterpots, I and laying Autumn's dust.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1; die bravely like&H4; a bridegroom, what? I will&H1; be
Jovial, come, come, I am a King my masters, know you that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are a royal one, and we&Htp; obey you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Then there is life in&H4; it, nay if you get it you shall get it
with running.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A sight most pitiful in&H4; the meanest wretch, past speaking of in&H4; a king: thou hast one daughter who&H61; redeems nature
from the general curse which&H61; twain hath brought her&H6; to&H5;.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Hail gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir speed you, what is. your will&H0;.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Do you hear aught of a battle toward.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Most sure and vulgar everyone hears that&H62;
That&H61; can distinguish sense.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: But by&H4; your favour how near is the other army.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Near and on&H4; speed for&H4; it the main descries,
Standest on&H4; the hourly thoughts.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I thank you sir that&H62; is all.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Though that&H3; the Queen on&H4; special cause is here,
Her&H2; army is moved on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: You ever gentle gods take my breath from me,
Let not my worser spirit tempt me again,
To&H9; dye before you please.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Well, pray you father.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now good sir what are you.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: A most poor man made lame by&H4; Fortunes blows,
Who&H61; by&H4; the Art&H0; of known and feeling sorrows
Am pregnant to&H4; good pity, give me your hand
I will&H1;. lead you to&H4; some biding.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Hearty thanks, the bounty and benison of heaven to&H9;
save thee.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: A proclaimed prize, most happy,that&H62; eyeless head of thine
was framed flesh to&H9; raise my fortunes, thou most unhappy traitor, briefly thyself remember, the sword is out that&H61; must destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now let thy friendly hand put strength enough to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Wherefore bold peasant durst thou support a published

traitor,hence lest the infection of his fortune take like&H2; hold on&H4;
thee, let go his arm?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: I will&H1; not let go sir without occasion.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Let go slave, or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Good Gentleman go your gate, let poor folk pass,
and I would have been swaggered out of my life, it would not have
been so&H51; long by&H4; a fortnight, nay come not near the old man,
keep out, che vor' ye, or I will&H1; try whether your coster or my battero be the harder, I will&H1; be plain with you.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Out dunghill.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: I will&H1; pick your teeth sir, come, no&H2; matter for&H4; your foins.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Slave thou hast slain me, villain take my purse,
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body,
And give the letters which&H61; thou findest about me
To&H4; Edmund Earl of Gloster, seek him out upon&H4;
The British party, o untimely death! death.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I know thee well, a serviceable villain,
As duteous to&H4; the vices of thy mistress, as badness would desire.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What is he dead?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Sit you down father, rest you let us&Htp; see his pockets
These letters that&H61; he speaks of may be my friends,
He is dead, I am only sorrow he had no&H2; other deathsman
Let us&Htp; see, leave gentle wax, and manners blame us&Htp; not
To&H9; know our&Htp; enemies' minds we&Htp; would rip their hearts,
Their papers is more lawful.
Let your reciprocal vows be remembered, you have many
sp.p:
opportunities to&H9; cut him off, if your will&H0; want not, time and place
will&H1; be fruitfully offered, there is nothing done, If he return the
conqueror, then am I the prisoner, and his bed my jail, from
the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply the place for&H4;
your labour, your wife (so&H52; I would say) your affectionate servant
and for&H4; you her&H2; own for&H4; Venture, Gonorill.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O Undistinguished space of woman's wit,
A plot upon&H4; her&H2; virtuous husband's life,
And the exchange my brother here in&H4; the sands,
Thee I will&H1; rake up&H5;, the post unsanctified
Of murtherous lechers, and in&H4; the mature time,
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death-practised Duke, for&H4; him it is well,
That&H3; of thy death and business I can tell.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The King is mad, how stiff is my vild sense,
That&H3; I stand up&H5; and have ingenious feeling
Of my huge sorrows, better I were distract,
So&H52; should my thoughts be fenced from my griefs,
And woes by&H4; wrong imaginations lose
The knowledge of themselves.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me your hand far off methinks I hear the beaten drum,
Come father I will&H1; bestow you with a friend.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O thou good Kent how shall I live and work to&H4; match thy goodness,
My life will&H1; be too short and every measure fail me.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: To&H9; be acknowledged madam is overpaid,
All my reports go with the modest truth,
Nor more, nor clipped, but so&H3;.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Be better suited these weeds are memories of those
Worser hours, I prithee put them off.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Pardon me dear madam,
Yet to&H9; be known shortens my made intent,
My, boon I make it that&H3; you know me not,
Till time and I think meet.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Then be it so&H52;, my good Lord how does the king.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Madam sleeps still.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O you kind Gods cure this great breach in&H4; his abused nature,
The untuned and hurrying senses, O wind up&H5;
Of this child-changed father.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: So&H3; please your Majesty that&H3; we&Htp; may wake the king,
He hath slept long.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Be governed by&H4; your knowledge and proceed,
In&H4; the sway of your own will&H0; is he arrayed,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I madam, in&H4; the heaviness of his sleep,
We&Htp; put fresh garments on&H4; him,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good madam be by&H5;, when we&Htp; do awake him
I doubt not of his temperance.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Please you draw near, louder the music there,

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O my deer father restoration hang thy medicine on&H4; my lips,
And let this kiss repair those violent harms that&H61; my two sisters
Have in&H4; thy reverence made.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Kilned and dear Princess,

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Had you not been their father these white flakes,
Had challenged pity of them, was this a face
To&H9; be exposed against the warring winds,
To&H9; stand against the deep dread bolted thunder,
In&H4; the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick cross lightning to&H9; watch poor Per du,
With this thin helm mine injurious dog,
Though he had bit me, should have stood that&H62; night
Against my fire, and wast thou fain poor father,
To&H9; hovel thee with swine and rogues forlorn,
In&H4; short and musty straw, alack, alack,
It is. wonder that&H3; thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all, he wakes speak to&H4; him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Madam do you, it is fittest.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: How does my royal Lord, how fares your majesty.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You do me wrong to&H9; take me out of the grave,
Thou art a soul in&H4; bliss, but I am bound
Upon&H4; a wheel of fire, that&H3; mine own tears
Do scald like&H4; molten lead.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Sir know me.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You are a spirit I know, where did you dye.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Still, still, far wide.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: He is scarce awake, let him alone a while.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Where have I been, where am I fair daylight,
I am mightily abused, I should even dye with pity,
To&H9; see another thus, I know not what to&H9; say,
I will&H1; not swear these are my hands, let us&Htp; see,
I feel this pin prick, would I were assured of my condition.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O look upon&H4; me sir, and hold your hands in&H4; benediction over me, no&H7; sir you must not kneel.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Pray do not mock,
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward, and to&H9; deal plainly
I fear I am not in&H4; my perfect mind,
Methinks I should know you,and know this man;
Yet I am doubtful, for&H3; I am mainly ignorant
What place this is, and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments, nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night, do not laugh at me,
For&H3; as I am a man, I think this Lady
To&H9; be my child Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: And so&H52; I am.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Be your tears wet, yes faith, I pray weep not,
If you have poison for&H4; me I will&H1; drink it,
I know you do not love me, for&H3; your sisters
Have as I do remember, done me wrong,
You have some cause,they have not.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: No&H2; cause, no&H2; cause.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Am I in&H4; France?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: In&H4; your own kingdom sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Do not abuse me?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Be comforted good Madam, the great rage you see is
cured in&H4; him, and yet it is danger to&H9; make him even over the time
he has lost, desire him to&H9; go in&H5;, trouble him no&H2; more till further settling:

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Will&H1; it please your highness walk?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You must bear with me, pray now forget and forgive,
I am old and foolish.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Holds it true sir that&H3; the Duke of Cornwall was so&H52; slain?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Most certain sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Who&H62; is conductor of his people?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: As it is said, the bastard son of Gloster.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: They say Edgar his banished son is with the Earl of
Kent in&H4; Germanie.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Report is changeable, it is time to&H9; look about,
The powers of the kingdom approach apace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The arbitrament is like&H5; to&H9; be bloody, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My point and period will&H1; be thoroughly wrought,
Or well, or ill, as this day's battle is fought.

stage.l: Enter Edmund, Regan, and their powers.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is advised by&H4; aught
To&H9; change the course, he is full of abdication
And self=reproving, bring his constant pleasure.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Our&Hrp; sister's man is certainly miscarried,

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: It is. to&H9; be doubted Madam,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Now sweet Lord,
You know the goodness I intend upon&H4; you,
Tell me but truly, but then speak the truth,
Do you not love my sister?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Aye, honoured love.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: But have you never found my brother's way,
To&H4; the forfended place?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: That&H62; thought abuses you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I am doubtful that&H3; you have been conjunctive and bosomed with her&H6;, as far as we&Htp; call hers.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: No&H7; by&H4; mine honour Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I never shall endure her&H6;, dear my Lord be not familiar with her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Fear me not, she and the Duke her&H2; husband.

stage.l: Enter Albany and Gonorill with troupes.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I had rather lose the battle, than that&H3; sister should
loosen him and me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Our&Hrp; very loving sister well be-met
For&H3; this I hear the King is come to&H4; his daughter
With others, whom the rigour of our&Hrp; state
Forced to&H9; cry out, where I could not be honest
I never yet was valiant, for&H4; this business
It touches us&Hrp;, as France invades our&Hrp; land
Not bolds the King, with others whom I fear,
Most just and heavy causes make oppose.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sir you speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why is this reasoned?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Combine together gainst the enemy,
For&H3; these domestic dore particulars
Are not to&H9; question here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; then determine with the ancient of war on&H4; our&Htp;
proceedings.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I shall attend you presently at your tent.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sister you will&H1; go with us&Htp;?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: No&H7;.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It is. most convenient, pray you go with us&Hrp;.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: O ho, I know the riddle, I will&H1; go.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: If ever your Grace had speech with man so&H51; poor,
Hear me one word.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I will&H1; overtake you, speak.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Before you fight the battle ope this letter,
If you have victory let the trumpet sound
For&H4; him that&H61; brought it, wretched though I seem,
I can produce a champion that&H61; will&H1; prove
What is avouched there, if you miscarry,
Your business of the world hath so&H52; an end,
Fortune love you,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stay till I have read the letter.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I was forbid it, when time shall serve let but the Herald
cry, and I will&H1; appear again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why fare thee well, I will&H1; overlook the paper.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: The enemy is in&H4; view, draw up&H5; your powers
Hard is the guess of their great strength and forces
By&H4; diligent discovery, but your haste is now urged on&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We&Htp; will&H1; greet the time.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: To&H4; both these sister have I sworn my love,
Each jealous of the other as the sting are of the Adder,
Which&H62; of them shall I take, both one or neither, neither can be enjoyed
If both remain alive, to&H9; take the widow
Exasperates, makes mad her&H2; sister Gonorill,
And hardly shall I carry out my side
Her&H2; husband being alive, now then we&Htp; will&H1; use
His countenance for&H4; the battle, which&H61; being done
Let her&H6; that&H61; would be rid of him devise
His speedy taking off, as for&H4; his mercy
Which&H61; he intends to&H4; Lear and to&H4; Cordelia:
The battle done,and they within our&Htp; power
Shall never see his pardon, for&H4; my state
Stands on&H4; me to&H9; defend, not to&H9; debate.

stage.l: Alarum. Enter the powers of France ouer the stage, Cordelia with

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Here father, take the shadow of this bush
For&H4; your good host, pray that&H3; the right may thrive
If ever I return to&H4; you again I will&H1; bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Grace go with you sir.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Away old man, give me thy hand, away,
King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter taken,
Give me thy hand,come on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No&H2; farther sir, a man may rot even here.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What in&H4; ill thoughts again men must endure,
Their going hence, even as their coming hither,
Ripeness is all come on&H5;.

stage.l: Enter Edmund, with Lear and Cordelia prisoners.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Some officers take them away,good guard
Until their greater pleasures best be known
That&H61; are to&H9; censure them.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: We&Htp; are not the first who&H61; with best meaning have incurred
The worst, for&H4; thee oppressed King am I cast down,
Myself could else outfrown false Fortune's frown,
Shall we&Htp; not see these daughters, and these sisters?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No&H7;, no&H7;, come let us&Htp; away to&H4; prison
We&Htp; two alone will&H1; sing like&H4; birds in&H4; the cage,
When thou dost ask me blessing, I will&H1; kneel down
And ask of thee forgiveness, so&H52; we&Htp; will&H1; live
And pray, and sing, and tell old tales and laugh
At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues
Talk of Court news, and we&Htp; will&H1; talk with them too,
Who&H61; loses, and who&H61; wins, who&H61; is in&H5;, who&H61; is out,
And take upon&H4; us&Htp; the mystery of things
As if we&Htp; were God's spies, and we&Htp; will&H1; wear out
In&H4; a wailed prison, packs and sects of great ones
That&H61; ebb and flow by&H4; the Moon.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Take them away.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Upon&H4; such sacrifices my Cordelia,
The Gods themselves throw incense, have I caught thee?
He that&H61; parts us&Htp; shall bring a brand from heaven,
And fire us&Htp; hence like&H4; Foxes, wipe thine eyes,
The good shall devour them, flesh and fell
Ere they shall make us&Htp; weep? we&Htp; will&H1; see them starve first, come.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Come hither Captain, hark.
Take thou this note, go follow them to&H4; prison,
And step, I have advanced thee, if thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To&H4; noble fortunes, know thou this that&H3; men
Are as the time is, to&H9; be tender minded
Does not become a sword, thy great employment
Will&H1; not bear question, either say thou wilt do it,
Or thrive by&H4; other means.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will&H1;. do it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: About it, and write happy when thou hast done,
Mark I say instantly, and carry it so&H52;
As I have set it down.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats,
If it be man's work I will&H1; do it.

stage.l: Enter Duke, the two Ladies, and others.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir you have showed today your valiant strain,
And Fortune led you well you have the captives
That&H61; were the opposites of this day's strife,
We&Hrp; do require then of you, so&H52; to&H9; use them,
As we&Hrp; shall find their merits, and our&Hrp; safety
May equally determine.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sir I thought it fit,
To&H9; send the old and miserable King to&H4; some retention, and appointed guard,
Whose age has charms in&H4; it, whose title more
To&H9; pluck the common bosom of his side,
And turn our&Htp; impressed lances in&H4; our&Htp; eyes
Which&H61; do command them, with him I sent the queen
My reason, all the same and they are ready tomorrow,
Or at further space, to&H9; appear where you shall hold
Your session at this time, me sweat and bleed,
The friend hath lost his friend, and the best quarrels
In&H4; the heat are cursed, by&H4; those that&H61; feel their sharps,
The question of Cordelia and her&H2; father
Requires a fitter place.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir by&H4; your patience,
I hold you but a subject of this war, not as a brother.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: That&H62; is as we&Hrp; list to&H9; grace him,
Methinks our&Hrp; pleasure should have been demanded
Ere you had spoke so&H51; far, he led our&Hrp; powers,
Bore the commission of my place and person,
The which&H61; immediate may well stand up&H5;,
And call itself your brother.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Not so&H51; hot, in&H4; his own grace he doth exalt himself
more than in&H4; your advancement.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: In&H4; my right by&H4; me invested he compeers the best.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: That&H62; were the most, if he should husband you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Jesters do oft prove Prophets.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Hola, hola, that&H62; eye that&H61; told you so&H52;, looked but a squint.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Lady I am not well, else I should answer
From a full flowing stomach, General
Take thou my soldiers,prisoners, patrimony,
Witness the world that&H3; I create thee here
My Lord and master.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Mean you to&H9; enjoy him then?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The let alone lies not in&H4; your good will&H0;.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Nor in&H4; thine Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Half blooded fellow, yes.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Let the drum strike, and prove my title good.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stay yet, hear reason, Edmund I arrest thee
On&H4; capital treason, and in&H4; thine attaint,
This gilded Serpent, for&H4; your claim fair sister
I bare it in&H4; the interest of my wife.
It is she is subcontracted to&H4; this Lord
And I her&H2; husband contradict the banes,
If you will&H1; marry, make your love to&H4; me,
My Lady is bespoke, thou art armed Gloster,
If none appear to&H9; prove upon&H4; thy head,
Thy heinous, manifest, and many treasons,
There is my pledge, I will&H1; prove it on&H4; thy heart
Ere I taste bread, thou art in&H4; nothing less
Than I have here proclaimed thee.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sick, o sick.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: If not, I will&H1; never trust poison.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: There is my exchange, what in&H4; the world he is,
That&H61; names me traitor, villain-like he lies,
Call by&H4; thy trumpet, he that&H61; dares approach,
On&H4; him, on&H4; you, who&H61; not, I will&H1; maintain
My truth and honour firmly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A Herald ho.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: A Herald ho, a Herald.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Trust to&H4; thy single vertue, for&H3; thy soldiers
All levied in&H4; my name, have in&H4; my name took their discharge.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: This sickness grows upon&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: She is not well, convey her&H6; to&H4; my tent,
Come hither Herald, let the trumpet sound,
And read out this.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sound trumpet?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
If any man of quality or degree, in&H4; the host of the
army, will&H1; maintain upon&H4; Edmund supposed Earl of Gloster,
that&H3; he is a manifold traitor, let him appear at the third sound
of the trumpet, he is bold in&H4; his defence.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sound? Again?

stage.l: Enter Edgar at the third sound, a trumpet before him.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ask him his purposes why he appears
Upon&H4; this call of the trumpet.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What are you? your name and quality?
And why you answer this present summons.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O know my name is lost by&H4; treasons tooth.
Bare-gnawn and canker-bitten; yet are I noble
Where is the adversary I come to&H9; cope with all.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Which&H62; is that&H62; adversary?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What is he that&H61; speaks for&H4; Edmund Earl of Gloster,

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Himself, what sayst thou to&H4; him?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Draw thy sword.
That&H3; if my speech offend a noble hart, thy arm
May do thee Justice, here is mine.
Behold it is the privilege of my tongue,
My oath and my profession, I protest,
Maugre thy strength, youth, place and eminence,
Despite thy victor, sword and fire new fortuned,
Thy valour and thy heart thou art a traitor.
False to&H4; thy Gods thy brother and thy Father,
Conspirant gainst this high illustrious prince,
And from the extremest upward of thy head,
To&H4; the descent and dust beneath thy feet,
A most toad-spotted traitor say thou no&H7;
This sword, this arm, and my best spirits,
As bent to&H9; prove upon&H4; thy heart whereto I speak thou liest,

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: In&H4; wisdom I should ask thy name,
But since thy outside looks so&H51; fair and warlike,
And that&H3; thy being some say of breeding breathes,
By&H4; right of knighthood, I disdain and spurn
Here do I toss those treasons to&H4; thy head.
With the hell hatedly, overturned thy heart,
Which&H61; for&H3; they yet glance by&H5; and scarcely bruise,
This sword of mine shall give them instant way
Where they shall rest forever, trumpets speak.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Save him, save him,

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: This is mere practise Gloster by&H4; the law of arms
Thou art not bound to&H9; answer an unknown opposite,
Thou art not vanquished, but cozened and beguiled,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stop your mouth dame, or with this paper shall I stopple
sp.p:
it, thou worse than anything, read thine own evil, nay no&H2;
tearing Lady,I perceive you know it.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Say if I do, the laws are mine not thine, who&H62; shall arraign me for&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Most monstrous knowest thou this paper?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Ask me not what I know.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Go after her&H6;, she is desperate, govern her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: What you have charged me with, that&H62; have I don
And more, much more, the time will&H1; bring it out.
It is. past, and so&H52; am I, but what art thou
That&H61; hast this fortune on&H4; me? if thou beest noble
I do forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; exchange charity,
I am no&H2; less in&H4; blood than thou art Edmond,
If more, the more thou hast wronged me.
My name is Edgar, and thy father's son,
The Gods are just, and of our&Htp; pleasant virtues.
Make instruments to&H9; scourge us&Htp; the dark and vicious
Place where thee he got, cost him his eyes.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Thou hast spoken truth, the wheel is come
full circled I am here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Methought thy very gate did prophesy,
A royal nobleness I must embrace thee.
Let sorrow split my heart if I did ever hate thee or thy father.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Worthy Prince I know it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where have you hid yourself?
How have you known the miseries of your father?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: By&H4; nursing them my Lord,
List a brief tale, and when it is told
O that&H3; my heart would burst the bloody proclamation
To&H9; escape that&H61; followed me so&H51; near,
O our&Htp; lives' sweetness, that&H3; with the pain of death,
