Would hourly die, rather than die at once.
Taught me to&H9; shift into a madman's rags
To&H9; assume a semblance that&H61; very dogs disdained
And in&H4; this habit met I my father with his bleeding rings,
The precious stones new lost became his guide,
Led him, begged for&H4; him, saved him from despair,
Never (O Father)revealed myself unto him,
Until some half hour past, when I was armed,
Not sure, though, hoping of this good success,
I asked his blessing, and from first to&H4; last,
Told him my pilgrimage, but his flowed heart,
Alack too weak, the conflict to&H9; support,
Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief,
Burst smilingly.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: This speech of yours hath moved me,
And shall perchance do good,but speak you on&H5;,
You look as you had something more to&H9; say,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: If there be more, more woeful, hold it in&H5;,
For&H3; I am almost ready to&H9; dissolve, hearing of this,

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: This would have seemed a period to&H4; such
As love not sorrow, but another to&H9; amplify too much,
Would make much more, and top extremity
Whilst I was big in&H4; clamour, came there in&H5; a man,
Who&H61; having seen me in&H4; my worst estate,
Shunned my abhorred society, but then finding
Who&H61; it was that&H61; so&H51; endured with his strong arms
He fastened on&H4; my neck and bellowed out,
As he would burst heaven, threw me on&H4; my father,
Told the most piteous tale of Lear and him,
That&H61; ever ear received, which&H61; in&H4; recounting
His grief grew puissant and the strings of life,
Began to&H9; crack twice, then the trumpets sounded.
And there I left him entranced.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But who&H62; was this.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Kent sir, the banished Kent, who&H61; in&H4; disguise,
Followed his enemy king and did him service
Improper for&H4; a slave.

stage.l: Enter one with a bloudie knife,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Help, help,

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What kind of help, what means that&H62; bloody knife?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is hot it smokes, it came even from the heart of -

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who&H62; man, speak?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your Lady sir, your Lady, and her&H2; sister
By&H4; her&H6; is poisoned, she hath confessed it.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I was contracted to&H4; them both, all three
Now marry in&H4; an instant.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Produce their bodies, be they alive or dead,
This Justice of the heavens that&H61; makes us&Htp; tremble,
Touches us&Htp; not with pity.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Here comes Kent sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O it is he, the time will&H1; not allow

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The compliment that&H61; very manners urges.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I am come to&H9; bid my King and master aye good night,
Is he not here?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Great thing of us&Htp; forgot,
Speak Edmund, where is the king, and where is Cordelia
Seest thou this object Kent.

stage.l: The bodies of Gonorill and Regan are brought in.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Alack why thus.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Yet Edmund was beloved,
The one the other poisoned for&H4; my sake,
And after slew herself .

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Even so&H3;, cover their faces.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: I pant for&H4; life, some good I mean to&H9; do,
Despite of my own nature, quickly send,
Be brief, in&H4; it to&H4; the castle for&H4; my writ,
Is on&H4; the life of Lear and on&H4; Cordelia,
Nay send in&H4; time.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Run, run, O run.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: To&H4; who&H62; my Lord, who&H62; hath the office, send
Thy token of reprieve.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Well thought on&H5;, take my sword the Captain,
Give it the Captain?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Haste thee for&H4; thy life.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: He hath Commission from thy wife and me,
To&H9; hang Cordelia in&H4; the prison, and to&H9; lay
The blame upon&H4; her&H2; own despair,
That&H3; she fordid herself .

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The Gods defend her&H6;, bear him hence a while.

stage.l: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Howl, howl, howl, howl, O you are men of stones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, I would use them so&H51;,
That&H3; heaven's vault should crack, she is gone forever,
I know when one is dead and when one lives,
She is dead as earth, lend me a looking glass,
If that&H3; her&H2; breath will&H1; mist or stain the stone,
Why then she lives.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Is this the promised end.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Or image of that&H62; horror.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Fall and cease.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: This feather stirs she lives, if it be so&H52;,
It is a chance which&H61; does redeem all sorrows
That&H61; ever I have felt.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Ah my good master.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Prithee away?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: It is noble Kent your friend.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: A plague upon&H4; your murderous traitors all,
I might have saved her&H6;, now she is gone forever,
Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little, ha,
What is it thou sayst, her&H2; voice was ever soft,
Gentle and low, an excellent thing in&H4; women,
I killed the slave that&H61; was a-hanging thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It is true my Lords, he did.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Did I not fellow? I have seen the day,
With my good biting Falchion I would
Have made them skip, I am old now,
And these same crosses spoil me, who&H62; are you?
Mine eyes are not of the best, I will&H1; tell you straight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: If Fortune bragged of two she loved or hated,
One of them we&Htp; behold.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Are not you Kent?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: The same your servant Kent, where is your servant Caius,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: He is a good fellow, I can tell that&H62;,
He will&H1; strike and quickly too, he is dead and rotten.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No&H7; my good Lord, I am the very man.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will&H1; see that&H62; straight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: That&H61; from your life of difference and decay,
Have followed your sad steps.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You are welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Nor no&H2; man else, all is cheerless, dark and deadly,
Your eldest daughters have foredoom themselves,
And desperately are dead.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: So&H52; think I too.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He knows not what he sees, and vain it is,
That&H3; we&Htp; present us&Htp; to&H4; him.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Very bootless.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Edmund is dead my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: That&H62; is but a trifle here, you Lords and noble friends,
Know our&Hrp; intent, what comfort to&H4; this decay may come, shall be
applied: for&H4; us&Hrp; we&Hrp; will&H1; resign during the life of this old majesty,
to&H4; him our&Hrp; absolute power, you to&H4; your rights with boot, and
such addition as your honour have more than merited, all friends
shall taste the wages of their vertue,and all foes the cup of their deservings, O see, see.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And my poor fool is hanged, no&H2;, no&H2; life, why should a
dog, a horse, a rat of life and thou no&H2; breath at all, O thou wilt
come no&H2; more, never, never, never, pray you undo this button,
thank you sir, O, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: He faints my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Break heart, I prithee break.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Look up&H5; my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Vex not his ghost, O let him pass,
He hates him that&H61; would upon&H4; the wrack,
Of this tough world stretch him out longer.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O he is gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: The wonder is, he hath endured so&H51; long,
He but usurped his life.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Bear them from hence, our&Htp; present business
Is to&H4; general woe, friends of my soul, you twain
Rule in&H4; this kingdom, and the gored state sustain.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I have a journey sir, shortly to&H9; go,
My master calls, and I must not say no&H7;.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The weight of this sad time we&Htp; must obey,
Speak what we&Htp; feel, not what we&Htp; ought to&H9; say,
The oldest have borne most, we&Htp; that&H61; are young,
Shall never see so&H51; much, nor live so&H51; long.
